I have died
I finished. 13 hours. I'm in hell.

You think you know pain? YOU DONT. This. This is pain. I have honestly not stopped sobbing for hours. I am broken. I woke up this morning (the day after finishing) and reread the last few chapters and I cried all over again.
I am broken and healing but every piece of my heart belongs to these books. (if you don't get that reference please get out of my life)
Let's discuss some early thoughts:
Was it as good as acomaf? Yes. They're equal at the moment but I have to reread this a few times to put it in perspective.
Was it more painful than acomaf? Hell yes. acomaf was just the beginning of hell.
Do you hate Tamlin? NOT AS MUCH AS I DID. I'll never forgive him for what he did BUT I don't want to kill him every second of every day now. I mean he did bring her to Rhys so thank you Tamlin ‚
Is Rhysand still the love of your life? Hell yes.
IS LUCIEN ABSOLUTELY AMAZING?! YES FUCKING YES OMFG! Lucien was a star in this book and I adored his story.
I loved Mor so much in this book guys. My heart BROKE for her over and over again like wowwww.
Azriel is a precious little cinnamon roll and he deserves a big freaking hug. I love the guy.
CASSIAN IS A HOT MESS AS ALWAYS AND I LOVE IT. His scenes with Nesta though damnnnnnnnn I have been slayed!
ELAIN IS A HIDDEN BAD ASS OH MY GOD I AM SHOOK AT HER CHARACTER DEVELOPMENT
AMRENNNNNN IS WILD! Oh my god my heart broke over and over with her too and holy shit I NEED MORE FROM AMREN!
As always

column1: The Hate U Give is one of those books.

I could tell you that this book is inspired by the ""Black Lives Matter"" movement. I could tell you that it rips unapolegetically into a subject that needed to be ripped into - the shootings of unarmed black people by police officers
column2: as well as racial bias in the justice system. I could tell you that it opened my eyes to aspects of white privilege I never considered. All of that needs to be said

column1: Though

column4: powerfully moving The Hate U Give .

column1: Starr is 16 years old. She feels like there are two of herâ€”the devoted daughter who lives in a poor neighborhood and saw her best friend get killed in a drive-by shooting when they were 10

column5: Chris

One night while Starr is at a party in her neighborhood
column2: she runs into her childhood friend Khalil. Khalil was her first crush

column1: Khalil's death throws Starr and her family into a tailspin. The media has already branded Khalil a drug dealer and a thug. Starr doesn't feel like she can tell her friends at school what happened because that would be exposing them to a part of her she has tried to keep hidden

column1: Why am I sharing this? I retired from traditional reviews--- but I may write a few NON- TRADITIONAL REVIEWS as my way to feel connected with people here I love and am forever thankful for!!!

GET THE CORRECT AMOUNT OF CALCIUM in my diet not under-eat... and get out of the chair. Writing reviews that take an hour or more won't build bone density.

column5: I can certainly see what all the uproar is about. 'The Hate U Give' addresses the very sensitive issues of race relations and police brutality in a time when the nation is torn over these issues. Most of my friends are at one extreme or the other when it comes to the #Blacklivesmatter movement. Since I don't want to incite an online mobbing
column6: I'm going to do my best to avoid that movement specifically
column7: while sharing my thoughts and opinions on this wonderful book.

column1: First of all
column2: this is a very moving story. It centers on a teenage black girl
column3: Starr Carter
column4: who leaves her crime-riddled neighborhood each day to attend an affluent school across town. In both settings
column5: she feels a need to conform to the social norms. This means that she lives a double-life of sorts -- she has one persona with her black family and friends in her neighborhood and another one with her wealthy
column6: predominantly white
column7: friends from her school.

column1: One night she attends a party in her neighborhood that turns violent. After leaving the party with her childhood friend
column2: Khalil
column3: her life and her community is forever changed. A routine traffic stop turns tragic when an unarmed Khalil is repeatedly shot by a police officer after failing to follow police instructions.

column1: The events of that night serve as the spark that sets off an explosion. Starr's neighborhood has a long-standing animosity for the police
column2: citing multiple instances of police brutality and harassment. The death of Khalil is only the latest in a long line of atrocities.

column1: Begrudgingly
column2: Starr is forced into the center of a media feeding frenzy. Part of her wishes that she could just hide and return to her ""old"" life
column3: while another part wants to be brave and stand up for what she believes is right. She was in an extremely difficult situation for a young girl.

column1: Although she initially tries to remain anonymous
column2: as the sole witness of Khalil's murder she eventually speaks out publicly. Doing so
column3: Starr learns a lot about herself and the people that she surrounds herself with. Some will stick around to support her
column4: others will reveal that they were never really who she thought they were.

column1: While this book certainly highlighted the issue of police brutality against blacks
column2: there were several other takeaways for me. I applaud the author for not shying away from other issues that are controversial. For example
column3: racism - against multiple races - was prevalent throughout this story. I appreciated that the author was forthcoming in addressing this topic
column4: even knowing that it would likely be controversial. Two wrongs don't make a right. Racism is still racism and it is wrong
column5: regardless of the race.

column1: Although I did find the danger of Starr's neighborhood to be exaggerated
column2: the author also highlighted the issue of violent crime
column3: drugs and gang warfare. Several times
column4: there were drive-by shootings or other crimes committed in Starr's neighborhood by the residents against the residents. It was sad and the author did a good job of highlighting this issue/cycle of violence.

column1: One notable
column2: older man in the story commented on this and I couldn't have agreed with him more. There was a lot of senseless violence and crime in Starr's neighborhood. As he said
column3: the government needn't look further than that neighborhood to find a real terrorist. The people lived in fear
column4: not only of the police
column5: but of the crime lord in their midst.

column1: The conflict in Starr's family over whether to stay in the neighborhood
column2: despite the danger
column3: or move to a safer neighborhood
column4: also was enlightening. There were a lot of mixed feelings and a sense of betrayal that accompanied her parent's desire to ""better"" their situation and that of their children. It reminded me of that saying about crabs in a bucket

column1: I honestly don't know how to review this book without spoilers and so from this point on there will be unmarked spoilers for the entire series.
***SPOILER ALERT TURN BACK NOW***
I feel as though this final installment was very disjointed.
We've got:
âœ”Perspectives tossed in here and there that ultimately amount to nothing.
âœ”Unnecessary emphasis on characters who haven't mattered at all in the first and second books.
âœ”A plot that takes almost 400 pages to really get going.
âœ”Questions raised without answers given.
âœ”A villain who feels neither scary
column2: nor provides a real reason for his being a villain.

column1: So the story begins right where A Gathering of Shadows leaves off. Lila runs off to save Kell and immediately kills Ojka. What was the purpose of creating this neat character
column2: giving us a glimpse of her background
column3: just to kill her off immediately? It felt rather pointless??

column1: Then we spend the next almost 400 pages listening to Kell brood
column2: Alucard jab at Kell while he broods
column3: Rhy float around from room to room (after he avoids death again)
column4: and being incessantly reminded that Lila is a cool chick.

column1: If you guys don't already know
column2: Kell and I don't get along. I don't sympathize with his plight
column3: and I find him unnecessarily mopey in most of his scenes (especially in the second book).

column1: I don't mind Alucard
column2: but I find his character to be a bit static. Even by the end of this book
column3: he doesn't grow into anything new and he doesn't really participate in the action scenes in a meaningful way. His sole existence in this story is to create drama for Kell
column4: Rhy
column5: and Lila.

column1: Rhy
column2: though not one of my favorite characters
column3: undeniably experiences the most growth of the four over the course of the book. He evolves his perspective on being given a second chance at life
column4: and ultimately comes to understand what it means to be king. SO bravo I guess on that front?

column1: Lila... Ugh. I want to like Lila so much but she's basically the same Lila we met on the streets in Grey London all those pages back.

Lila's character on her own doesn't bother me as much as the way the Schwab handles telling us about her. I got weary of reading phrases like ""thief-soft footsteps"" and ""she was a mystery"" used to describe her. Like... I get it. She's interesting & capable. You don't need to keep reminding me.
Outside of these characters
column2: we get chapters devoted to random one-time characters that don't really add up to anything
column3: and we get chapters about King Maxim & Queen Emira & Tieren that don't really add up to anything.

column1: Throwing in perspectives like Nasi
column2: a little girl from White London who admired Ojka
column3: did absolutely nothing for the plot or the world building. This character appears two times
column4: around page 140 and around page 520
column5: but her existence bears no consequence on the story.

column1: Using this character to explain more about Ojka's background could have worked
column2: but since ultimately Ojka didn't end up mattering either it amounted to nothing more than a waste of time.

column1: Adding perspectives like Ned Tuttle & King George IV was so incredibly boring
column2: since once again nothing of consequence happens in Grey London while this plot unfolds.

column1: Writing about Maxim and Emira was too little
column2: too late for me. For the first two books
column3: we've known these two to be side characters. This sudden shift to semi-main character status was jolting.

column1: We only scratched the surfaces of the King's and Queen's lives
column2: and there simply wasn't enough there for me to connect to. I felt completely unattached to them
column3: so their eventual deaths were reduced to plot devices for Rhy's development instead of being meaningful on their own.

column1: After a huge stretch of monotony
column2: the plot finally gets itself going when the crew arrives at the floating black market. Here is where I started to become interested in where the story would go. The Inheritor was an interesting solution even if it's existence felt very tailored for defeating Osaron.

column1: For the last 200 pages I was engaged
column2: but pretty disappointed that the resolution of the plot played out exactly the way it was supposed to. Hell
column3: it played out better than it was supposed to really
column4: seeing as Holland survived to see the plan through to completion.

column1: No twists. No surprises. Our four main characters all survive. The end.
Now I'm left wondering:
What about Kell's past? Sure he decided he was better off not knowing about his true parents
column2: but what about me as the reader? Resolving this question with Kell deciding he doesn't need the information was lazy on part of the author.

column1: What about Lila? Where did she come from? How did an Antari originate in Grey London? How did she lose her eye
column2: and why? No
column3: we are too busy being reassured that Lila is sly and mischievous and special to worry about her past
column4: I suppose.

column1: How did the original tokens get into the different Londons? Can we know a little more history so that these worlds don't all feel like cardboard?

What exactly caused Osaron to manifest into Vitari? Shouldn't we be looking for a solution to this problem since this is the second time it's happened? Maybe a way to eliminate the threat that Black London poses by just existing as a magical black hole that spits out perilous villains every so often?
And that brings me to Osaron himself. He just doesn't scare me.
When I read A Darker Shade of Magic
column2: for the first 100 or so pages I was totally and completely enticed by the threat that Osaron presented. His unwanted presence felt menacing and dangerous in Red London and I was intrigued.

column1: But by A Conjuring of Light
column2: he's still... just possessing people? Sure
column3: they're chanting some creepy shit. Sure
column4: he's killed a couple unimportant side characters.

column1: But... Is that all you got?
Oh
column2: and he creates an obsidian replica of the palace for... posturing? Intimidation?

column1: Once all the citizens of Red London are asleep
column2: he's back to being a temperamental
column3: smoke bitch until he's defeated at the end
column4: which wraps up nicely and neatly and quickly in the last 50 or so pages of the book.

column1: I'm not impressed by Osaron.
All three of these books suffer severely from pacing issues
column2: on both a microcosmic and macrocosmic scale. Each book begins with a slow to medium pace
column3: then concludes in a rapid whirlwind of events which is jarring to say the least.

column1: The series takes place over the course of what
column2: a couple months? Maybe 4? Sometimes this can work
column3: but in this case I don't feel it did.

column1: I wish Lila had been gone for two years instead of two months. It would've made much more sense for her to come back after two years of studying with Alucard to feel confident enough to enter the Essen Tasch.
It would've given all of these characters time to grow into people I cared about.
Now
column2: perhaps you noticed I have been neglecting to mention Holland.

column1: That's because Holland was undoubtedly the star of the show.
Holland's moments were such a treat for me. I was immediately entranced by him
column2: and I drank in every one of his stories that Schwab graced us with.

column1: We get his backstory. We understand his motivations. We glimpse the events that have shaped him
column2: hardened him
column3: softened him. Holland's development causes the others' to pale by comparison.

column1: He possessed a depth I could sink my claws into. His death in the Silver Woods was beautifully tragic
column2: and wonderfully appropriate. I just wanted to wrap him in my arms and die with him.

column1: If this series had been about Holland
column2: I would likely be giving it 5 stars right now.

column1: Aside from Holland
column2: Schwab's writing once again is absolutely stunning. This is an author who always impresses me with her writing style. She is whimsical in her descriptions
column3: unique in how she conveys emotion to her readers. I am truly a fan of reading her words.

column1: But this series just did not deliver for me. I craved more intensity. I needed more unpredictability. I wanted meaningful characters that danced their way into my heart & a rich world that beckoned me to keep turning the pages.
What I found here was a superb concept with a less-than-superb execution. (less)",65,NEXTBOOK

column1: Be ready because the moment you open this book... you'll hit the ground running. It picks up literally seconds where the second left off... and it doesn't slow down. The first 20-30% was non stop craziness... and it was wonderful and painful and entirely too stressful and I found myself screaming and laughing and I don't even know.. you guys... I don't even know.
The only slow moments in this ENTIRE book were the flashbacks - and there were lots of little ones all throughout. They were very core to character development and I actually really enjoyed them.

I literally cannot even begin to talk about the plot. I'm going to refrain from giving away any details. But I'll say this- I really liked the first book though I felt it was slow at times. I LOVED the second as it took the series to a whole new level of emotional turmoil. This one just blew me away. The pacing was perfect (as I said
column2: VERY fast paced
column3: only slowing during flash backs) and full of surprises (and stress). I was so attached to everyone (even the side characters) that I was literally racing through the pages so now I'm going to have to go back and reread for details. I've highlighted about 30 quotes. column1: Writing a conclusion to a series is hard. It happens so (so so so) often that I'm 100% thrilled by a series and then 100% disappointed with the last book. column2: when I was desperately pining for it for a whole year? What was I scared of? Yup
column3: you guessed it: Disappointment.

column1: ALL THE STARS !!!

column1: I LOVED THIS BOOK !!
Just like it says in the title of the book
column2: Eleanor Oliphant is completely fine....well she thinks she is. She is honestly not worried that she may be missing out on anything. She is content with her life.

column1: Eleanor is a little bit....odd. She's very intelligent and well-spoken with impeccable grammar (thanks to Mummy) but she lacks the ability to filter what she says and therefore she will tell you exactly what she's thinking. This can lead to very awkward situations.
Eleanor is comfortable with her routines. She's worked at the same job for nine years. She starts work at 8:30
column2: at lunch she buys a newspaper which she reads from cover to cover and then does the crossword. She finishes out her day
column3: leaving work at 5:30. Eleanor listens to the Archers as she makes a simple dinner (usually pasta and salad - one pan one plate)
column4: watches TV or reads for a little while then off to bed at ten. Her weekday routine only changes on Wednesday when she talks with ""Mummy"" for ten minutes.

column1: Weekends are a bit different. After work Friday she picks up pizza
column2: wine and two big bottles of Vodka for the weekend. She drinks the vodka over the weekend.....in a state where she's neither drunk nor sober
column3: waiting for Monday to come. No one comes over and she doesn't go anywhere to visit. She sometimes wonders if she's a figment of her own imagination.

column1: But she's fine with it. She's fine. There's nothing missing
column2: she doesn't need anyone else. Well that was what she told herself. But then it happens...

column1: He was light and heat. He blazed. Everything he came into contact with would be changed. I sat forward on my seat
column2: edged closer. At last. I found him""

column1: Now Eleanor is on a mission. First she decides a make-over is in order....and where she starts is both shocking and hilarious. I really want to write about what happened but I think I would spoil a very funny moment for many readers.
Things don't go exactly as planned.
When her computer at work stops working she meets Raymond from IT. An easy-going guy
column2: Raymond is intrigued by Eleanor
column3: but she's just not interested. She's busy trying to re-create herself for the man of her dreams. But after work one day Eleanor and Raymond come across a man who has fallen on the sidewalk. Together they help the man
column4: Sammy and so begins a friendship along with the start of many changes in Eleanor's life.

column1: The story is told from Eleanor's point of view. We go along for the ride as she navigates her way through her life
column2: learning to stand up for herself. But it won't be easy. Secrets and memories that have been tucked away for many years can be painful to remember.

column1: When you have trouble with social skills I can see how it would be easier to refrain from situations where things could go wrong so fast..... It would be easier being alone. As I mentioned there are many funny moments throughout the book. I really like how the author wrote these parts. I never felt like I was laughing AT Eleanor but at the things she said or the situations she ended up in. However
column2: there are also many sad and painful moments. Times where I felt terrible for Eleanor.

column1: Some of the funniest parts came out of nowhere - the phone doesn't ring often but if telemarketers call Eleanor whispers ""I know where you live"" and hangs up. Often it was what she would be saying to herself that was funny.
An incredible read that had me bouncing from one emotion to the next. The author did a tremendous job bringing these wonderfully unique characters to life.
It's hard to believe this is the author's debut novel.
There are so many words that can be used to describe this novel - hilarious
column2: unique
column3: heartwarming
column4: heartbreaking
column5: charming
column6: hopeful
column7: inspiring
column8: and COMPLETELY unforgettable.

Eleanor Oliphant is Completely Fine caught me completely unawares. I'll be honest - I picked it up because it got some buzz and the author is British

column1: I read a lot of books and many characters come and go. Some are well-developed and interesting
column2: others less so. But on a rare occasion I find one of those truly memorable characters that will stay with me a long time. Eleanor is one of them. She is socially clueless in a way that puts my teen self to shame. She is literal to a degree that everyone finds odd. It's painful to witness and yet so
column3: so endearing.

column1: I think I like this book so much because it is actually really sad
column2: but never manipulative. On a surface level
column3: it's a very funny novel about a socially-inept twenty-nine year-old woman. Her attempts to become ""normal"" and integrate into society by having manicures and waxes are sources of hilarity. But it is very sad. It's sad when we see her coworkers talking about her
column4: but Eleanor is oblivious to their scorn. It's sad how alone in life she is. It's sad when she ""falls in love"" with an idea of a person.

column1: It's not a romantic book and I'm glad. There are hints that the central relationship will eventually develop into romance
column2: but this is really a book about Eleanor. I am thankful that the author didn't cure Eleanor and lead her out of the darkness by having her fall in love. Being happy and achieving greater self-worth should
column3: in my opinion
column4: never be linked to romance.

column2: The Night Circus. But Caraval has easily set its place right next to The Night Circus as one of the most magical stories I have ever read.

column1: I can't even put into proper words how magical this book truly is. Of course I can't speak for everybody

column1: + The world was actually incredible.

It's like set in this mysterious carnival type island world. So think: gondolas and weird tunnels and magical shops and doors that change directions and rooms that grow and shrink with your emotions. It was like Alice in Wonderland but SINISTER and with a vague circus vibe and like set IN VENICE. Duuuude. I like. I LOVE it when buildings have their opinions though lowkey am curious why that room didn't crush Scarlett because that would've been exciting. BUT OK.
+ The writing was rather beautiful too.

Except for that line where she likened a kiss to ""giving birth to the dawn"" or whatever and I'm like...mate. You do not put BIRTH and KISS in the same thought with a guy you just met. Ya know. Anyway. I really liked all the vivid descriptions! It didn't feel too flowery but just added to the magical vibe. So so much magical vibes.
+ Mind twisty!

They start off the book saying ""nOTHING IS WHAT IT SEEMS"" and Scarlett promptly forgets that 2 seconds later and freaks out over everything. I would like to stuff her in a shoe. But it was really really well done!! I had SO many questions. It tossed me about a LOT. And I questioned everyone adn decided they were all evil by page 3. So basically: I had a freakin good time. I loooove worlds that are so morally grey and all ""IT'S A GAME AND EVERYONE'S GONNA GET STABBED!"" I mean. Monopoly was so yesterday.
+ Okay but real talk: Scarlett...why.
Just why. She was the typical: ""I am a good and wholesome creature."" sort of character who informed us 87 x per chapter that she was GOOD. Aka
column2: super boring. I do think she had good character development
column3: but if a bucket had narrated it would've been just as exciting. Which is weird that I still love the book a LOT even if Scarlett is as stimulating as that plastic fork over yonder?? Nice.

column1: + SISTER STORY!!

column1: + The romance was honestly super BITTER and I liked it.

column1: 3.5 stars
Anytime a book is surrounded in as much hype as CARAVAL
column2: I try to go into reading it with lowered expectations.

column1: BUT.
Said hype seldom stops me from actually reading it. Not b/c I'm a lemming
column2: but b/c curiosity. *shakes fist at curiosity gods* That being said
column3: beyond the pretty
column4: pretty cover and the quote
column5: ""It's only a game
column6: I had no prior knowledge of the contents when I first cracked its spine.

column1: The concept is intriguing: two sisters
column2: raised by an abusive father
column3: run away to play a game whose winner will be granted a single wish. That's oversimplification
column4: but I don't want to spoil you
column5: so that's all you get. *orbit gum smile*

column1: The problem is the execution.
A lot of new authors make the mistake of browbeating their readers with key details:
1. Ever since their mother abandoned them
column2: Scarlett has felt responsible for the well-being of her younger sister Tella.

column1: 2. Above all things
column2: Scarlett desires escape from her father. But only if the escape provides safety and security.

column1: 3. Tella is reckless.
But instead of these ideas being vocalized once
column2: then reinforced by demonstrations
column3: we're simply told (over and over again) by an increasingly fretful and exasperating Scarlett. And once Scarlett gets to her destination
column4: it only gets worse
column5: b/c we know the things she repeatedly tells us are untrue.

column1: Little to no world-building.
The only things we know about Scarlett's world are:
1. It has magic and that magic is a tricksy fae sort of magic.

2. The part of the world that Scarlett and her family live in is conquered (by we-don't-know-who) and travel is restricted. But this information feels more like a plot device to explain Scarlett's inability to travel freely than actual world-building.
Ringmaster's island is more developed
column2: but it felt like a Stardust /Diagon Alley/Disney mashup
column3: so MEH.

column1: Then there's other weird stuff like how Scarlett assigns colors to emotions
column2: an obvious sign of her own magical ability
column3: which is never addressed. We just get a lot of very specific shades that mean very specific things (sometimes nonsensically)
column4: except for when the colors don't mean anything at all . . . But are still very specific
column5: which is confusing and a little bit weird.

column1: Cerulean blue . . . Apricot orange . . . Saffron yellow . . . Primrose pink. OR if you're familiar with my peeves
column2: blue blue
column3: orange orange
column4: yellow yellow
column5: and pink pink. *flares nostrils*

column1: BUT.
By the end
column2: I had either grown immune to Scarlett's fretting or she'd calmed down--I can't be sure which--and I wasn't quite as annoyed by her as I'd been for the first three-quarters of the book
column3: which allowed me to appreciate the ingenuity of the tale.

column1: SO.
Although I don't think CARAVAL by Stephanie Garber comes close to living up to the hype
column2: I don't regret reading it
column3: and I'll probably read the next book. Garber is clearly capable of dreaming up not-your-ordinary-story
column4: she just needs a bit of polish. Recommended. Ish.

column1: There is always something mystical in the way Cassandra Clare writes. While her writing skills keep improving
column2: the essence of her novels remains the same. In Lord of Shadows
column3: she weaves a story of yearning
column4: passion
column5: bitterness
column6: anger and desire. Desire painted with fevered touches and swollen lips and cheekbones illuminated by moonlight and hearts clenching with unspoken feelings. Her descriptions are lavish
column7: her battle scenes intense
column8: and her characters gloriously flawed. From the land of Fairie and unhallowed churches to Idris and the London Institute that sparked a strong pang of nostalgia she whispered stories of cursed love

column1: If you know me
column2: you know I love Chaol Westfall to bits and pieces and he's one of my all-time favorite male characters. And here's where I get all emotional about him. I've loved him ever since ToG and still loved him through everything he went through. I would defend him to my last breath and I would fight anyone who insults him. Chaol is a pure soul. He's loyal. He's honorable. He's strong. He's brave. He's human. He's flawed. He's real. All of the things he went through from ToG to QoS changed him as a person and the way he dealt with things was completely realistic. Yes
column3: he made his own mistakes
column4: but again
column5: that makes him real. Don't you always complain about needing realistic
column6: flawed characters? Chaol Westfall is one. Chaol Westfall deserves all that's good and beautiful in this world. Thank you.

column1: With the events of ToG till QoS
column2: it all broke Chaol. Tower of Dawn did not only serve as a book where Chaol seeks healing and hopes to get more allies
column3: but also it was his emotional journey. He was so broken at the beginning of the book. Filled with despair and self loathing. He learns to forgive himself. By the end of the book
column4: he's come to terms with a lot of things and he rebuilds himself all over again. He has hope by the end of the book. He's no longer drowning in guilt and self loathing. And I was honestly in tears throughout the majority of the book because Chaol's emotional journey hit me. It was so intense and real and raw and I applaud SJM for doing it so realistically and so beautifully! I've said it a million times before and here I am saying it again

column6: I think it was even more emotional. I've been waiting for Chaol to find happiness and peace since CoM and he finally did in this book and oh lord

I love how his nose got broken by a fairy tale book and that he'll walk into a wall because he's reading so much and how his whole life is about fantastical lost cities and how he dreams the most beautiful and gorgeous dreams the world has ever known. Every once in awhile I enjoy a paranormal/fantasy type of story
column4: but it definitely isn't my go-to genre. Yet
column5: Laini Taylor has managed to suck me in once again. The beauty of her words and the vivid imagery that she creates never ceases to amaze me.

column1: This book centers on Lazlo Strange
column2: aka ""Strange the Dreamer"". An orphan
column3: he has never really had a home or felt like he fit in. The closest he's come to a sense of normalcy is during his time in the Great Library. He grows up to become a librarian
column4: submersing himself in the stories that he loves so much.

column1: More than anything else
column2: he is captivated by tales of the ""unseen city"". He remembers hearing the stories about the city and the travelers that used to return from having crossed over the city's borders. Then one day
column3: the city seemed to be forgotten. Unlike everyone else in his town
column4: Lazlo remembers the feeling of having his memory of the name of the city pulled away from him. In it's place is the name ""Weep"".

column1: When a mythical hero
column2: the Godslayer
column3: arrives in town
column4: Lazlo is able to join the group on their quest for Weep. This is his biggest dream come to life. He finally has a chance to see the legendary city that he's only fantasized about.

column1: What awaits Lazlo is more than he had imagined. Mythical beings
column2: age-old grudges and a history that melded the worlds of gods and men. As more of Weep's past is unearthed
column3: the brutality of the city's past is brought to light. Lazlo is forced to look at the city and it's inhabitants through a new lens.

column1: Although Lazlo was the central focus for much of this story
column2: Ms. Taylor provides a robust cast of characters. Each member of this large cast brings something special to the story. I don't want to say too much for fear that I might spoil this story for others.

column1: Sarai is such a character. Her relationship with Lazlo is essential to the progression of the plot. From his dreams to his reality
column2: Lazlo could not have found a better match than Sarai. They made each other better for having known one another. Their relationship was sweet and innocent
column3: but also intense and emotional. I loved watching their bond evolve and seeing how their actions changed how they viewed the ""outside"" world.

column1: From start to finish
column2: this was an entertaining and captivating story. Laini Taylor's writing is poetic. You can't help but notice the beauty of her prose.

column1: I listened to the Audible version of this book and it was well-narrated. My only criticism is that it was a bit hard to follow at first. This author's works are multifaceted and incredibly detailed. At first
column2: this can be a bit difficult to follow when listening. I did have to rewind a few times in the beginning to keep my characters and events straight. However
column3: I was able to get it all sorted out pretty soon and I wouldn't trade the richness of the story for the small amount of time lost.

column1: Overall
column2: I thought that this was a wonderful story! I would definitely recommend it
column3: whether you're a die-hard fan of paranormal/fantasy or if you're just an occasional dabbler
column4: like me. Laini Taylor has created a fantastical and intriguing world. I am looking forward to seeing where this series will go.

column1: Hockey has never been my thing. I grew up in the deep south where football is praised more highly than any other sport
column2: but baseball was where my friends and I found ourselves watching games in high school. Most of my guy friends were on the team
column3: and I remember the awe inspiring excitement we felt at every win and the crushing agony of each loss. I attended a small private school that wasn't known for it's ability to crush it's opponents in sports
column4: but during my high school years we had an exceptionally good baseball team (2 of our players ended up playing professionally years later). It was difficult for our school to get behind the idea of team spirit and to fan the flame of hope when we were crushed in each game season after season
column5: but I remember the anticipation that began to grow amongst the student body those years. This experience is what allowed me to fully succumb to the excitement of the hockey scenes in this story. Hockey is a large piece of this book and I'd go as far as suggesting that hockey is it's own character in the novel
column6: but it wasn't from an overly technical point of view. I found that the overall plot and the hockey scenes awoke that same feeling I used to have while watching high school baseball and it brought to life a sport I never dreamed I could become entranced by. I think Backman said it best when he wrote ""Hockey is like faith. Religion is something between you and other people
column7: it's full of interpretations and theories and opinions. But faith... that's just between you and God. It's what you feel in your chest when the referee glides out to the center circle between two players
column8: when you hear the sticks strike each other and see the black disk fall between them. Then it's just between you and hockey. Because cherry trees always smell of cherry trees
column9: whereas money smells of nothing.""

column2: business sponsors

column1: With a robust cast of characters

column1: More than anything else

column3: to homophobia

column1: This book was an emotional rollercoaster. At times

column1: Without a doubt

column6: a 2016 contemporary novel by Fredrik Backman. Although the book had a bit of a difficult start for me
column7: it developed into an emotionally-charged hot bed
column8: triggering anger and frustration over so many things about the human race... and I'm quite glad I read it and enjoyed it. But wow... I haven't a visceral emotional reaction to words like this in a very long time.

column1: Why This Book
Beartown began showing up on a few of my Goodreads' friends booklists earlier this year
column2: intriguing my interest. I read the overview and saw many comments that ""although the premise of all about a junior hockey team
column3: it's so much more."" I had a hard time believing that to be true but thought it might be worth a chance if I could get it from NetGalley. And then I was approved to read it in early April. It took me a few weeks to find the right time in my reading schedule
column4: but it all fell into place last week when I finally took the book on. Also of note: itâ€™s translated from Swedish.

column1: Overview of Story
Beartown is a very small town in the middle of a forest far away from everywhere else. It was once bigger and stronger
column2: but the economy has pushed it further and further down a hole -- to the point where all they have left is the possibility of a good junior hockey team in the future. Everyone in the town gets involved to some degree
column3: either playing
column4: supporting or raising the players who range from 13 to 17 years old. It's the place where agents sometimes go to find the next great star of the professional leagues.

column1: But the lack of resources and funding has led to a bitter passion among the residents
column2: who seem to stop at almost nothing to ensure their kids have an opportunity to win their games. Some of the residents are fair and honest. Some are rude and malicious. It feels like a typical American sports town
column3: (but the story is set in Sweden) breeding team camaraderie fueled in some cases by hatred and anger
column4: but in a few
column5: promoting acceptance and tolerance.

column1: Each of the key team members (8 to 10) has a personal story. Each of the parents and coaches have a vision. Rivalries and favoritism shine all around. And with each passing game
column2: the school decided what side of the coin they're on... supporting the team and accepting hockey will always comes first
column3: before education
column4: or fighting back to keep a fair balance. But when someone is attacked
column5: sides must be taken within the school
column6: the team
column7: the hockey league and the town.

column1: It's a story about hope
column2: control
column3: loss
column4: jealousy
column5: anger
column6: and desire. It's about parenting styles. It's about looking the other way for the sake of long-term goals despite what you may be letting someone get away with in the short term. It's about how people treat one another. And in so many cases
column7: it is not the way it should be.

column1: Approach & Style
Beartown is told by an omniscient narrator who can look into any characters head at any moment.
It's told in the present tense with a few small reflections on the past.
Point of view changes and hops around within chapters
column2: defined by a few spaces between paragraphs.

column1: It's mostly short sentence structure and paragraphs. Told the way people speak.
Strengths

1. I am not a big sports fan. I played on a soccer and baseball team when I was younger. And I worked for a sports arena for nearly 20 years. But I have never been interested in hockey. And while the story is too focused in the beginning on the pertinent parts of the sport and rules
column2: it generally has a very good approach to building a fever for the team among us readers. When an author can do that
column3: it's a strong book.

column1: 2. The characters are fairly vivid
column2: each representing a difference slice of life and personality. You will like a few. You will hate many of them. It's another good thing when an author can deliver this level of emotion. As an example
column3: Maggan Lyt supports her son no matter what he has done. And she's rude to everyone
column4: lies
column5: believes her own lies and has no sense of morality. She wasn't a huge part of the story
column6: but she is the epitome of what I hate about what sports can do to a kid. She's the worst kind of mother and should have been taught a bigger lesson. (I rarely go off on topics
column7: especially like this... but she is what is wrong with so many things right now about how people behave in this world...)

column1: 3. The setting is described nearly perfectly. You feel the despair. You see the emptiness. You can tell it's a freezing cold pit of fear.
4. Views are told from everyone's angle. And even though you will have pure hatred for some of the people
column2: part of you has a small understanding of why they do what they do. You won't accept it or like it
column3: but you can see how it happened in Beartown. And you will wonder if that's what's happening in so many other towns across the country.

column1: Open Questions & Concerns
During the first 60 to 75 pages
column2: I was a little frustrated at the focus on hockey as a sport the town rallied around. It was slightly boring and difficult to connect. I trudged through
column3: reading 75 pages the first night and the second night. By the third night (last night). I was 35% through and starting to feel that intense sensation where you just don't want to put the book down
column4: and I finished the last 300 pages all in one sitting (in bed). Intense because I was so angry at the people
column5: the actions and their beliefs. It made me feel sorrow for any town who focuses on sports as the center of their life. I've always thought high school sporting teams were full of nonsense. I don't want to alienate any readers of the book or even my reviews... but I really have to ask the question... Do school sports breed teamwork or do they breed arrogance and nasty habits of accepting things just because you're on the same team? I'm sure there are good examples of a team building positive traits in children... but this was not one of them. When they're proud to have injuries... when they support someone who has clearly done something bad because they are on the same team... when they use derogatory language in a locker room because it helps create a bond... that's not teamwork. That's humanity at its worst... that's people thinking they are above others because they have some physical talent for playing a sport. I have little if any tolerance or patience for people like that. Even when I played on teams
column6: sure
column7: I bought into the ""rah
column8: rah
column9: let's win"" concept. But the second it crosses that line and because a situation where it's just bad behavior or the thoughts of the uninformed and lazy
column10: ridiculous politics of small minds
column11: I wish they'd all go straight to hell in a hand-basket. And that's how this book made me feel - it conjured up those feelings.... and it was really well done. It hit all the hot spots I have about awful sports parents
column12: horrible team members who think they can do anything because they're a ""hero.""

column1: I couldn't push this up to a perfect 5 for a few reasons
column2: but it's very close!

column1: 1. Some of the characters felt too similar / duplicate. I had a bit of a hard time distinguishing them from one another
column2: e.g. which parent is that
column3: what happened to that kid before the game? It could have been a little tighter in this area.

column1: 2. I'm a bit unclear on the ending... it was like there were 2 possible versions... and I wanted to know exactly what happened. It also didn't feel like every character had a proper ending... a few open issues left for me.
Author & Other Similar Books
I haven't read any other sports-themed books
column2: so I don't have anything to compare it to from that perspective. But as far as the intensity of your anger or hatred for some of the characters... I would liken it to how I felt about James K. Morrow's The Philosopher's Apprentice.

column1: Final Thoughts

I've ranted a bit here. It's a powerful book. It showcases many of the fears I have about a good portion of the country. I'm all for team spirit and finding hope in an activity when there seems to be nothing else available
column2: however
column3: if this is a commentary on what it's like for many towns across the world... my fears are justified. And when a book can share and show that... it's a really strong one... and worth the read.

column1: P.S. No offense intended to anyone who is a big sports fan
column2: sports parents or sports player themselves. The anger I felt in reading this book is for the negativity steaming off all the wrong things about sports and how they make people act. I'm all for a positive
column3: character-building team sport where the intensity is on the field... and the only thing left off the field is friendship
column4: fair and honest support and an ability to know when to draw the line.

column1: So guys this was one of my favourite series but this book just made me so upset. I hate it!!!! I feel to laugh in Mare's face at the end. Bitch. I am so happy that that happened! I think that's one of the only positives. Oh and these are just my taught and opinions
So I finally decided to do a proper review.

I gave this book 2*. I won't lie the first half was enjoyable. The sarcasm was on point and I loved the whole weird feelings and relationship between Mare and Maven. It was interesting and reminded me so much of Unravel Me that it just broke my heart.
The whole plot with Cameron and Cal and crew was just a yawn fest for me.

However I finally realised what people mean about Mare. My eyes was finally open to see how she is a self centered bitch. Everything must revolve around her or else she will find a way for the plot to become so. For example Maven stayed away from Mare for like about a month and because she was bored and felt as if he was not paying her any attention she made it her duty to get his attention. Its ridiculous. Why does the author goad on readers in a certain direction and just totally do the opposite by the end of the book? Why give me hope? I can understand if you don't fool readers and tell them about one thing but then and stick with that. Then there is no reason to get angry. But when you make me feel one way and then just snatch it away???? Just for fan reaction I get angry and pissed.
Anyway so the plot pretty much was non existent. You can skip this one really and go on to book 4.

Surprisingly I liked Cal better in this book than the last. I totally understand why he did what he did. Once again Mare cough*ass* tries to make him feel bad. Cal is so much more than the author makes him out to be. He reminds ma a bit of Chaol though.

I just have a bad feeling that Maven will die in the next book. I hope not. I really do. At this point I can just read an entire book from his perspective. My heart broke for him in this book. Such a strong character. I feel so sorry for him. Why can't Maven just be happy and get a good ending? Is it too much to ask????? Maven is a character who needs time and his character needs to be fleshed out properly so that he can be understood and not misread.Come on Victoria. You can do better. (view spoiler) Gonna say this now: if book 4 turns out the way i hope then i will totally try to look pass the sheer stupidity of this one. Anyway let me stop my rambling for now. May or may not read the last book.

column1: WARNING! This review will contain spoilers. I will first talk about non-spoiler stuff then I'll switch to a spoiler chat. If you have not read King's Cage
column2: then don't continue. Or if you don't have any intention on reading the Red Queen series
column3: then welcome.

column1: To say I was disappointed would be correct.
To say that I was glad I was done reading King's Cage would also be correct.
EpicReads (who I like) overhyped the hell out of this series. It's not the best series ever
column2: but it isn't bad. The Red Queen series is just a mixture of every YA dystopia/fantasy ever. The series isn't something new. Not to mention how several people are saying Victoria ripped off Red Rising by Pierce Brown. (Darrow. Mare Barrow. Caste system by color. Royalty
column3: etc.) So the series isn't something to write home about. But it's entertaining. But boy this series is pretty... meh.

column1: There's also been controversy about Mare's ethnicity and skin color. In the book trailers
column2: the actress who portrays Mare is white. Also
column3: there wasn't a clear description of Mare in Red Queen. So I
column4: and I'm sure a lot of people
column5: thought Mare was white. Later
column6: in the second book
column7: Victora wrote Mare as being olive skinned. And cue the controversy. This was a problem to people for two reasons.

column1: 1) Mare's sister
column2: Gisa. Gisa has red hair. I'm not a genetics expert so don't take my word as 100% accurate
column3: but if Mare is olive skinned
column4: how does Gisa have red hair if red hair isn't common in olive skinned people or of darker colors? Victoria said something about genetics which
column5: like I said
column6: I'm not a genetics expert (not to mention there isn't a clear description of Mare's parents' skin tones)
column7: so I'm not sure how this works.

column1: 2) There have been people accusing Victoria of commercial tokenism. (I just want to say upfront that I am not accusing Victoria as this. If she had Mare olive skinned from the beginning
column2: then Mare is olive skinned.) When it comes to authors writing characters of different ethnicities
column3: sexual orientation
column4: and skin color
column5: it comes naturally because... people like them exist. It's organic and feels natural. Victoria on the other hand never said what Mare REALLY looked like in the first book. And in book 2 and 3
column6: her skin color is described better (Even though based on the book trailers
column7: the actress was white). Of course
column8: it's been a year since I've read book 1 and I might have missed something. It's great to have POC. This is the opinion of some people
column9: not mine. Though Victoria didn't do a good job of properly explaining this whole fiasco. Not looking good for you
column10: Victoria.

column1: Enough about that
column2: onto the review!

column1: This is definitely the weakest book out of the series so far. And who knows how the last book will end. There were times where I was bored reading about Mare and... well
column2: mainly bored in general. This book is all just filler
column3: descriptions
column4: and dialogue with little action spread out. I hate books like that. But before I talk about King's Cage
column5: let me give you a run-down.

column1: So Mare (if you Google Mare
column2: it means a female horse. A horse. Smooth one
column3: Victoria) has been captured by Maven and is a prisoner in his palace. Mare is incapable of using her powers and is trapped. She must find a way to escape in order to tell the Scarlet Guard what Maven is planning on doing.

column1: As interesting at the premise is
column2: the book failed to capture my attention as well as having little to no character development for Mare. Literally
column3: the first 2/3rds of the book was filler and the last bit was rushed action. Aside from that
column4: nothing else happened. Just talking and talking and talking and descriptions and more talking and more talking and *snore*

column1: Based on the premise alone
column2: this book was mainly political with a few talks of war tactics in it. That's all fine and dandy
column3: but it was BORING!!!

column1: Look
column2: I've read the Winner's trilogy and that was a politically based series and I liked it. The plot kept me invested and the character growth and development helped keep me interested. King's Cage failed on all aspects of being a politically based book. All we got was Mare being a cry-baby
column3: feeling sorry for herself and very little action.

column1: I kid you not
column2: 70% of the story is filler and the 30% is actual plot/action. There has to be an even balance between the two. The Winner's trilogy did that well. Not King's Cage.

column1: Luckily
column2: Cameron and another character saved the book. Cameron is without a doubt my favorite character in the series. I love her personality and her snarky attitude. She is probably the only character who sees how big of a mess the Scarlet Guard is and is not afraid to say it. She's blunt and I love it! The other character
column3: I was surprised we got to see from her perspective. I wasn't expecting that. I can see how she may not be a favorite character to others
column4: but I love how Cameron says things how they are. No sugarcoating
column5: no holding back.

column1: In this book
column2: we get three POVs. Mare
column3: Cameron
column4: and... someone. (Trying to keep this part spoiler-free as much as possible.) I'm half and half about this format. Half of me liked it because I didn't have to read from Mare's POV as often (not to mention I get to read from Cameron's POV). But on the otherhand
column5: I didn't see how this helped. Parts of it felt like chunks of the story was left out. Plus
column6: the majority of it was Mare's POV. Which... ugh. I get that with these three characters
column7: they offer insight on what each one is doing and what they're doing
column8: but it didn't do a good job at it sometimes.

column1: Though this may be simple and small
column2: I have to say it. Victoria is not good with naming people
column3: cities
column4: and countries. There's a map in the book and the name of the cities are not good. Like Victoria just jumbled up some words to make them seem like a fantasy name and went with it. Nevermind that some names are lazy.

column1: Now
column2: let's get to the nitty gritty and talk about the book and characters.

column1: WARNING! WARNING! SPOILERS AHEAD! WARNING! WARNING! SPOILERS AHEAD!
Mare.
Fucking Mare Barrow.
(Yes
column2: I will refer to her as a horse from now on.)

column1: I don't when know where to begin with this shit of a character. This annoying
column2: whining
column3: self-absorbed pathetic excuse of a character.

column1: Mare really got on my nerves sometimes. She is by far
column2: the worst character I have ever encountered in a book/series. Victoria tries to write her as this brave and powerful girl who is the face of a rebellion when in reality
column3: she is a self-centered
column4: whiny
column5: bratty horse. You couldn't have picked a better name
column6: Victoria??? Half of the time

column9: in the end

column11: she's pissed. Grow the fuck up
column12: Mare and please kindly fuck off.

column2: Cal was being Emo McBroody and that did not help him with his development. Emo McBroody over here was pining for Mare (why I have no idea?) and was struggling with his allegiance to the Scarlet Guard and the Silvers. Look
column3: Cal
column4: I understand this is a hard time for you

column1: Cameron.
She is hands down
column2: the best character ever! She was the only character I was rooting for. She had one goal and one goal in mind: rescue his brother. When she did
column3: I thought she would be leaving the Scarlet Guard. Even though she didn't
column4: I'll still root for her.

column1: Maven.
Maven Maven Maven. Maven. My little Darkling copycat. (Who am I kidding
column2: no villain can top the Darkling.) Throughout King's Cage
column3: we get more insight on Maven and his plans to rule Norta. During Mare's captivity
column4: we find out that Elara had manipulated Maven throughout most of his childhood to make him a perfect prince. Doing so
column5: she also altered his feelings of Cal and his father. Maven says he loved them before
column6: but that it's gone. It kind of made me sad to see him be reduced to this because of his mother. I'm not saying he's a good character
column7: but he's been manipulated to be a villain. Thank God Elara is dead. Even so
column8: he still hasn't changed. And it's clear that he's in love with Mare. Even Mare herself was confused by Maven and his feelings. Clearly
column9: she doesn't like him
column10: but there's something in her that wants to be close to him. Or rather
column11: close to who he was before. Seeing how he is in the end
column12: I doubt he'll get a good ending.

column1: Evangeline.
I was surprised by her appearance. I knew Victoria said there would be a third character with her own POV
column2: but I wasn't expecting Evangeline. Even though she didn't have much story time
column3: we get to know what she and her family is planning. When Mare was rescued by the Scarlet Guard
column4: Evangeline and her family escaped. Turns out
column5: her family
column6: along with other royal houses are planning on overthrowing Maven. Clearly
column7: they aren't happy with recent developments and are now rebelling against Maven and the Lakelands. With this turn of events
column8: I'm actually starting to root for Evangeline. Fuck the Scarlet Guard. Evangeline is where it's at!

column1: Kilorn is there. At least he didn't have a big role in this book and we didn't see much of him. I still want him to die. He better die in the next book.
The Scarlet Guard? Fuck them. They are a rebellion I can't see myself rooting for. Half the time they don't even know what they're talking about. And the other half they're being hypocrites.
There's also something I want to mention. It's pretty obvious that Norta and the other nations/countries/whatever are the result of a war-torn North America. If you look at the map
column2: it's clear that Norta is based on the North-East part of the States and the Lakelands consists of a small part of the States and the majority (I assume) is Canada. And by war-torn
column3: I mean bombs and possible nuclear bombs. My theory (and this is just a theory
column4: it's not 100% fact) is that before the events of Red Queen
column5: bombs were set off in the States and possible nuclear bombs. I believe that the nuclear bombs are what gave the Silvers their powers. Plus it has been said in Glass Sword that the Silvers were persecuted by the Reds because they were different and had deadly powers. Eventually
column6: the Silvers had enough and used their powers to rise to the top and make the Reds be on the bottom because of what they have done.

column1: Now
column2: does this mean the Silvers are in the right? No
column3: but it is understandable that the Silvers had had enough of the Reds persecuting them. I do feel bad for the Reds
column4: but they are now trying to dismantle the Silver hierarchy and live in peace. The problem with that
column5: is the Scarlet Guard seem to care more about Reds being the rulers and the Silvers being at the bottom. History repeats itself and the Reds are a perfect example of that. They think they're trying to make a difference and change
column6: but they're making things worse by creating a war between Reds and Silvers. This is why I cannot root for the Scarlet Guard.

column1: As said previously
column2: this is supposed to be a politically based book. Since Mare is forced to attend events and parties with Maven
column3: she learns about alliances between the different states/countries and their leaders. Later on in the book
column4: Maven is betrothed to the princess of the Lakelands (A.K.A. Canada)
column5: sealing an alliance between the two. With the uprise of the Scarlet Guard and other Reds rebelling
column6: Maven needs more power. And what better way than to marry the princess of an enemy country? I actually enjoyed this part of the book. But I also want to knock some sense into Maven. Yes
column7: I'm still in the ship of MarexMaven and I was kind of mad he did this. WHY?!?!?!?!

column1: One last note
column2: I had heard that Victoria doesn't really respond well to criticism. I don't know if this is true
column3: but if it is
column4: then Victoria needs to deal with it. Victoria
column5: people aren't going to like your book. Deal with it.

column1: Verdict
There were parts of King's Cage that were entertaining
column2: but the negatives outweighed the positives. Cameron and parts of the book were the only things I liked. Other than that
column3: the rest was just plain bad. The weakest of the series. I believe the last book will be in big trouble if Victoria doesn't change Mare.

column1: Thanks for reading my review!
-Cesar (less)",347,NEXTBOOK

column1: Meanwhile the Scarlet Guard and Cal spend their time organizing and preparing for war. Their alliance with Montfort provides them with much needed supplies and power as well as other New Bloods with experience and training to train the ones the Scarlet Guard has been recruiting. Only time will tell though about Montfort's own intentions for helping the Scarlet Guard and what the price of the alliance may be.

I think this would have been my favorite of the series and even ended up on my favorites shelf if not for a few things. First off I didn't really enjoy Cameron or Evangeline's POVs. I mean it was necessary to keep the reader informed about what was happening outside of Mare's imprisonment but like I love Mare and I can't stand people hating her so I automatically got annoyed with Cameron and Evangeline. I can't help myself because no matter what Mare does I'm just like it's ok I love you always. Second I don't know how much of the history we've started to get I buy into. I understand that they have a certain level of technology and understand genetics but I feel like it was implied both of those have been known about for a while and so I'm wondering why no progress on either end was made? It just feels strange that all of this has existed long enough without anything new happening but long enough for a mutated gene to take over so much of the gene pool. It just seemed in Red Queen that the book was taking place in a time without as much advancement but I guess not. It just doesn't feel coherent and I don't buy it but I'm willing to keep reading and see where this is going. Third I still don't care at all about Cal. He's such a boring character and so cliched. The dark brooding hero. Like go away Cal.
Otherwise I really enjoyed this book. I like that we're getting a more complex picture of the world and the politics in it

column1: Turtles All the Way Down is really only for those looking for deep cell-level evaluation of human consciousness and personhood. To give him some credit
column2: Green captures Aza's needling anxiety and compulsions very well. That little inner voice of doubt that causes you to question things you know until maybe you're not so sure is spot on. It's everything else around Aza's inner turmoil that feels like what it is - filler.

column1: It could very easily have been an interesting portrait of OCD and anxiety

column4: especially in YA contemporary dealing with mental illness

column6: of course
column7: it is yet another ""deep metaphor"" for the nonsensical nature of anxiety
column8: but I would have found Aza's story far stronger without it.

column1: The ludicrous and boring plot acts as a superficial backdrop for Green to play out the usual ""super precocious teens having philosophical conversations."" Aza's mental illness and Green's philosophy bleed together into statements that are straddling the line between clever and nauseating:

column1: I don't know why Green has to create such annoyingly unrealistic carbon copies of himself. Even secondary characters like Daisy quickly become annoying - calling Aza ""Holmesy"" in literally every sentence she speaks is extremely irritating. And these text messages between Aza and Davis:
Me: Youâ€™re not your money.

column1: Green takes steps toward exploring the painful reality of living with a mental illness that deeply affects your everyday life and wellbeing

I'm actually floored by how good it was. I mean
column4: I haven't read a ""new"" John Green novel in forever
column5: but this is worth the wait. I wasn't actually nervous going in. It's about mental health (#OWNVOICES I REMIND YOU) and missing persons and smol sad rich boys and everything about this just shouts that it's my kind of novel. It really really hit home so hard for me. I loved it.

column1: OK note on the title: I see a lot of people complaining about the lack of turtles and like...I'm sorry but I'M LAUGHING. HAVE YOU NOT MET JOHN GREEN. It's a metaphor!! The title of the book being a metaphor is like perfect. (I mean no one complained about the towns not being made of actual paper in Paper Towns so I don't even get how everything thinks this is different.) THE BRAND IS ON POINT.
Anyway. Excuse me. I have an enthusiasm for this book.
+ OK so the plot was really amazing!

Bit slow but really really good. I loved that it wasn't rife with cliches or annoying tropes. It was just so pure almost. It felt actually real. It's not really a ""detective"" story (I thought it was going to be??) but Aza is lowkey curious about the mission millionaire because she used to know his son
column2: Davis. She does a bit of digging
column3: but she does more investigative work on Davis. So.

column1: + Aza was honestly amazing.
She is EXTREMELY quiet. She probably hardly ever talks and she's very much locked in her own head. And I HATE that that's a negative. Because be in your own head if you want
column2: I say. I appreciated that she's quiet and that she thinks a lot. She's obviously extremely intelligent. ALL JOHN GREEN'S CHARACTERS ARE. I love how ""pretentious"" they are because I was 100% like that as a kid. Let's talk about the stars and metaphors and what poetry means and the infinite possibilities of death and life. The sheer amount of knowledge these kids spew out is just refreshing and perfect to me. I am HERE for smart people. (Also because I'm not one so it'sl ike??? Nice. Thanks. Let me osmosis the intelligence.)

column1: + The anxiety/OCD was really brutally and honestly talked about.

The only thing I'm angry about is that the word ""OCD"" is never used. I actually hate when books do this and it would've made me really upset reading if I hadn't already have known from listening to vlogs/interviews. I'm the kind of person who wants to KNOW and have solid answers. And I think OCD should've been stated because...liek this isn't your typical ""oh she lines everything up and washes her hands 298 times a day"" sort of OCD that books like to present. This is the real and brutal version of OCD. And the fact that we get like the thought-spirals and the psychology behind it is what is the BEST in my opinion. You are not watching someone with OCD
column2: you are experiencing what it's like to have OCD while reading this book. And that's freaking important ok.

column1: + I have mixed feelings about Aza and Daisy's friendship tho...
I mean
column2: I LOVED them as friends but then Daisy (view spoiler) Aaaanyway. Still (mostly) a good female-to-female- frienship that WASN'T built on obsessing over boys or being catty! YAS.

column1: + AND CAN WE TALK ABOUT DAVIS? WHO IS SUPER ADORABLE AND I LOVE HIM.

It was like SUCH a cute romance. Slow and cautious and fraught with problems just from Aza's OCD and Davis insurmountable grief. He was also the BEST big brother ever and I just... <3 <3 I loved how geeky and nerdy and beautiful he was. Honestly. DAVIS.
+ It's also really DEEP.
Like it talks psychology a lot and some of the metaphors were really intense and like wow. It was so layered. I LOVED it.
+ And yes I teared up at the end.

I mean. It's a John Green novel. I LOVED the ending and I hated it and I LOVED IT and just ajfdsakld I have at least 4 emotions which is double as many as I usually have. Goddamn. I'm not used to this I need to sit down.

ALL IN ALL: I think this is an absolutely deep and existential book that really discusses minds and who we are. It's sad and it's not sugar coated. Liking a boy doesn't make Aza ""better"" (lol @ that trope
column2: John Green dismantles it SO WELL) and there's no messages that you need to be fixed to have a good life. Your mental illness isn't ALL of you
column3: but it is some of you. And as someone who has anxiety disorders too
column4: I really appreciated this. I appreciated the whole heckin' book.

column1: FOREVER A JOHN GREEN FAN.
Anybody can look at you. It's quite rare to find someone who sees the same world you do.
(new favourite quote of ever) (less)",369,NEXTBOOK

column1: I went into this with a bowl full of low expectations but with a side of high expectations. And it tasted good.
It's been a while since John wrote a book. The first John Green book I ever read was TFIOS
column2: which I loved. During the time that passed until the release of Turtles All the Way Down I caught up with most of his other books
column3: apart from An Abundance of Katherines. Will Grayson
column4: Will Grayson was meh but Paper Towns and Looking for Alaska straight up sucked. It made sense that I was torn whether I wanted to read TALWD or not. But I'm glad I did.

column1: The plot wasn't all the exciting. I saw lots of people complain about an absence of plot
column2: but some stories are more character-driven than others
column3: as in this case. Apart from this
column4: there were lots of subplots that I loved - Daisy's relationship with Mychal for once
column5: or the disappearance of Pickett Senior.

column1: The characters were fantastic. First and foremost there is Aza
column2: a teenage girl battling with anxiety. While she did not say much
column3: I enjoyed her narratorial point of view. She was a fleshed out character with lots of depth
column4: which is such an improvement to John's previous main characters that were part boring and part even more boring. Now
column5: I don't struggle with an anxiety disorder. I can't possibly judge this novel from that perspective because I never experienced anything similar to what Aza struggles with on a daily basis. But this book managed to make me feel what a person with an anxiety disorder might possibly have to go through - so much that I could only skim the parts where the main character's anxiety surfaces and takes over all her thoughts and actions.

column1: With Daisy
column2: Aza's best friend
column3: it was love at first sight. This girl is precious. I loved everything about her.

column1: I never warmed up Davis
column2: Aza's love interest
column3: if that is what you want to call him. I don't think that I fully got him and I'm not entirely sure why Aza was drawn to him. On one hand
column4: their relationship lacked romance
column5: on the other hand
column6: I'm glad that this was not one big love story. It would not have fit into the story.

column1: Overall I simply liked this novel. Money was one of the story's central themes
column2: and while I'm both uncomfortable with and in awe of this unfathomable wealth depicted in it
column3: I also deeply connected with Daisy
column4: when she talked about what being poor can be like. Of course
column5: wealth and poverty are extremely subjective topics and people hate to talk about money
column6: but I think John Green managed to find a good balance.

column2: John Green was one of the first authors I'd read that introduced me to the magic of books. I owe a lot to his writing that sucked me in so completely
column3: only to leave me craving for more by the last page

column1: It all begins with a fugitive billionaire and the promise of a cash reward. Turtles All the Way Down is about lifelong friendship
column2: the intimacy of an unexpected reunion

column4: and tuatara. But at its heart is Aza Holmes

column2: heightening them until they become metaphor.

column1: The story gets off to a slow start because of the character introductions and the focus on the teenagers
column2: but I was still completely engrossed in their lives. It really took off for me when the adoption plot starts about one-third of the way through
column3: especially in relation to Mia's backstory. There are so many interesting questions raised: Is it biology or love that makes a parent? How important is the role of cultural heritage in upbringing? But by the end
column4: I felt like the author played favorites with the characters. For all the focus on complexity and gray areas
column5: sometimes it felt too simplistic. Elena got more one-dimensional as the story went on. The adoptive parents were treated with such tenderness at first
column6: but by the time the trial rolled around I kept having to remind myself that hadn't literally snatched the child out of the biological mother's arms. I love the feeling of having my sympathies pulled in a million directions
column7: but here I felt reflexive resistance as my sympathies were yanked to one side. The scales tipped towards Mia a little too much and my contrarian side started rearing its ugly head. Mia is often described as enlightened and empathetic
column8: but she's just as flawed as anyone else. Mia's selfishness and hypocrisy are not as emphasized as Elena's flaws and she got off extremely easy compared to other characters. It's not that I don't understand her actions
column9: but there were issues regarding parental rights and the importance of family bonds that I wanted to see Mia wrestle with more directly.

column1: Sometimes you need to scorch everything to the ground
column2: and start over. After the burning the soil is richer
column3: and new things can grow. People are like that
column4: too. They start over. They find a way.

column1: The arrival of Mia and Pearl Warren is the spark that sets of series of little conflicts that culminates in the Richardson's house being set ablaze
column2: but there was already plenty of fuel to feed the flames. Despite the best-laid plans
column3: things don't always go the way we expect. Mrs. Richardson thinks she prepared her kids for life so well that they will never get into tough situations and they will always make the ""right"" decisions
column4: but life is more complicated than that. Sometimes people don't realize how affecting the consequences of their actions will be
column5: because of lack of experience or circumstances beyond their control. Situations are never as clear-cut as they look from the outside. There are so many instances in this book when people make snap judgments based on an incomplete picture. Uncharitable
column6: simplistic assumptions are made when there are actually complex
column7: relatable explanations. As I read
column8: I was reminded of a Stephen M.R. Covey quote: ""We judge ourselves by our intentions and everyone else by their actions."" I didn't fall in love with Little Fires Everywhere as much as Everything I Never Told You
column9: but it's still a captivating and thought-provoking sophomore novel. I just didn't get everything I wanted from the wrap-up
column10: perhaps because I was most interested in the adoption storyline.

column1: The story for me was about more than the storyline though that was certainly interesting. What resonated with me was Ng's depiction of relationships. The relationships between mothers and their children
column2: the relationships between friends
column3: the relationships between siblings and the complicated relationships between family members. Ng powerfully explored these relationships and wasn't afraid to showcase how at times we seem to hurt those we love the most because of our own unhappiness
column4: apprehension or feelings of inadequacy. I loved how flawed and real the relationships were in this novel.

column1: Another standout for me was the exploration of motherhood. In Elena Richardson and Mia Warren we see two polar opposite mothers. Elena very rigid
column2: proper
column3: opinionated and the epitome of success within her town. Mia with her bohemian lifestyle was in contrast artsy
column4: free and openly loving. Their lives would intertwine when Mia and her daughter Pearl rent an apartment from the Richardson's. Pearl becomes smitten with the Richardson's children and their life. Izzy
column5: the youngest Richardson child
column6: in turn becomes smitten with Mia. Each child essentially finds something they are missing in the other family. For Mia it is an open acceptance
column7: understanding and love. For Pearl who was an only child
column8: always on the move - it is a house full of siblings with more things than they could ever need.

column1: This is a story that unfolds as the lives of the characters unravel. The characters were well written and complex. They all had layers to them
column2: that were skillfully peeled away as Ng skillfully weaves her story. ""Weaves"" is the perfect word here as the story is connected by a host of characters and linked through many different relationships and actions. We see why they behave the way they do
column3: we come to understand their actions even if they are wrong.

column1: Overall
column2: this book was very definitely enjoyable. I wholeheartedly enjoyed the explorations into the characters. I was simply never wowed by it so while I enjoyed it

column4: but reading it in a middle grade book
