column6: was the last straw. It prompted me to finally write something about this vastly growing issue.

column1: There I was
column2: happily content to be reading some fun Rick Riordan mythology again
column3: when suddenly a huge sign with the words LIBERAL BRAINWASHING AHEAD popped up. You know when you're in the middle of watching a YouTube video and a thirty second ad interrupts that just about ruins the whole video? Yeah
column4: that's how it felt when Riordan decided to throw some of his political views into this book.

column1: The worst part is this book is for kids. Children are reading this. Children as young as eight should not be subject to adult matters - such as a lesbian couple
column2: which this book promoted in chapter six.

column1: Would people be okay if someone wrote about a drag queen in a children's book? What if child characters went to a strip club? No? Then why
column2: I ask
column3: is it okay to put a lesbian couple
column4: portray two women living together
column5: and promote your own shameless political agenda
column6: in a book meant for young
column7: easily impressionable minds?

column1: Whether you support the LGBT+ community or not is beside the point. People have the right to hold whatever opinions they want. But I think all adult matters should be kept out of kids' entertainment
column2: and it's horrible when adults try to sneak it in because they think it's ""funny"" or they're trying to push their own personal agenda.

column1: War
column2: alcoholism
column3: suicide
column4: sex
column5: prostitution
column6: or any other adult things should not be put in children's books. Adults keep those topics away from children for a reason - they're too much for them to handle. And I don't think sexual identification should be put in children's books either
column7: when the young minds reading them haven't even begun to develop sexually yet.

column1: Look
column2: my whole problem wasn't even that there were gay characters in this book. My problem was that Riordan was so obviously including them just for the sake of ""representation."" Representation of different groups is a great thing
column3: and I love when I come across a genuinely diverse bookâ€¦ but when the author is trying so hard to make their book diverse to earn brownie points
column4: it comes across as unnatural and takes away from the story.

column1: Anyway
column2: the gay thing is so overdone by now it's getting ridiculous. It's one thing when you have an actual gay character like Radu from And I Darken and it makes sense for them to be gay. But when you throw in a gay character just to get your LGBT+ brownie points and they're only in the book for
column3: like

column5: I would be insulted by this ""representation.""

column1: Itâ€™s probably invalid to criticise an author for not doing something he had no intention of doing but Iâ€™m going to do it anyway. Hamid is so caught up with presenting a big picture that he often seems to neglect his characters. Sometimes theyâ€™re unable to articulate his ideas so he introduces a fleeting character of convenience who can. It was like the ideas of this book left his two central characters behind. At times it can seem more like some kind of brilliantly imagined essay than a novel. Perhaps thatâ€™s not necessarily a bad thing. Iâ€™m all for extending the boundaries of what a novel can achieve. But his virtual indifference to developing character began to make this novel seem like the literary equivalent of an air-conditioned environment for me. There was no weather. There was one particular moment when I most strongly felt this. The two refugees are in London and face racism and xenophobic nationalism in the form of a rioting crowd. The entire scene is depicted as if through a wide angle lens. Itâ€™s impersonal in nature. I couldnâ€™t help feeling it would have been much more powerful and emotionally engaging had the author shown these two refugees being racially insulted close up by a small group of individuals and wondering why he didnâ€™t do this. Racism at its most emotionally disturbing for me is when I see footage of one or more individuals insult another individual face to face. When the hate and hurt caused are of a highly personal nature. Thatâ€™s when empathy for the victim is at its most powerful. And as a result of the impersonal nature of the hostility it seemed to have little effect on the character of the characters. They just drifted off to the next location with barely a metaphorical scratch. As the novel progressed the camera angle got wider and wider until I could barely make them out anymore. The ideas utterly dwarfed them. It felt more and more like this novel was written as a warning and the central thesis felt like a corset the characters were forced to wear which prevented them from developing as characters. They ended up little more than shadow shapes flitting over the globe â€“ on the one hand brilliantly indicative of a universal modern truth but on the other frustrating from the point of view of my need to relate to the characters I read about.

Exit West is a tough one to star rate. Probably the most straightforward way to rate a novel is simply by how much you enjoyed reading it. If someone hated reading The Waves or War and Peace then why shouldnâ€™t she give it one star irrespective of how much literary merit it might have? column1: The Tenth of December"" was the number 1 best seller for months and months.....

I remember thinking another 'lesser name' --- at the time --RISING today--was the OUTSTANDING collection of short stories -that people ought to be talking about .... by Peter Tieryas Liu for his book called ""Watering Heaven"".....
A collection of short stories that 'still' blows me away to this day! -- The stories all that place in China. Brilliant book!

NOTE: I'm the type of reader who usually doesn't need to read more than the blurb. I prefer going into a book almost 'blind' - as long as my gut feeling towards it is thumbs up.

A cyber bet - of an imaginary coin toss - which I won - finally made me realize - I'm not getting out of reading this book ..... so I simply surrendered!
AND MY GOLLY.... THE HYPE IS REAL!!!! It's really REAL!!!! This book is OUTSTANDING ..... IT 'is' at times like a Greek Chorus ......

column2: by Mark Zusak

column1: Now

column3: grief
column4: and love.....mixed with history of the times......and moving on ... and letting go ... and letting go ... and letting go........ A father's love for his son ---the grimmest of prognosis --hurts deeper than hurt.

column1: GEORGE SANDERS created a deeply emotional beautiful heartbreaking journey.

column1: Willie hovers in a transitional stage much akin to the Tibetan Buddhist belief of existence between the finality of death and the renewal of a new dimension of life....the bardo. It is within this bardo that George Saunders introduces us to a marching caravan of individuals who will swing your head back and forth in amazement. Death has not become a reality for the majority of them quite yet. We are given brief glimpses into their former lives which may or may not satisfy the hunger to know more and to unveil their uncertain relevance to this story.

column1: And it's not so easy to mask the simplicity
column2: the lack of creativity
column3: in Roth's latest work. Divergent had just enough quirks to make it stand out against the odds - the use of factions an exciting reminder of Hogwarts' houses for old Potterheads
column4: and a new personality quiz for younger readers. Even those feeling underwhelmed were quick to take a faction quiz to see where they fell (Candor - thanks for asking!).

column1: What does Carve the Mark have to make it stand out? I honestly don't have an answer.

The world is very simplistic. The Xmen-like powers are nothing we haven't seen before hundreds of times. The politics are uninteresting and the villain is mindlessly evil without any depth or development.

I said in a status update that there had been some confusion over the physical descriptions of the characters - that the violent savages are actually described as ""so pale he looked almost like a corpse"" and the pacifist Thuvhe people have ""light brown skin"" and ""dense
column2: curly hair"" - but the reality is only marginally better than the rumours. Having a violently savage race vs. a gentle race without it being adequately addressed is arguably always problematic
column3: it arguably always has troubling real-world connotations. And
column4: even if you disagree with that assessment
column5: at best it's just plain lazy.

column4: I should preface this with a few key points. I work for a bookstore and received an ARC of this book through my job. All opinions are my own. This review is not an attack on the author
column5: the publisher
column6: or anyone else. I am also white
column7: and I am aware this affects my position to call something out as racist. I find that it's helpful to raise awareness of problematic representation in the media we consume.

column1: In regards to advance copies being sent out to reviewers
column2: I've noticed in a lot of Goodreads reviews that the bloggers state either at the beginning or the end of their review that HarperTeen (HT from here on out) sponsored these reviews. Further research led me to discovering that HT paid this set of bloggers to review Carve the Mark. This behavior from a publisher is unsettling. Generally speaking
column3: if one is going to be paid for reviewing something
column4: one will not review the thing unfavorably (and if one reviews unfavorably
column5: that reviewer runs the risk of tarnishing the relationship with said publisher). This behavior by the publisher is akin to self-published authors paying readers to post positive reviews of the work in order to boost sales. That's what I feel like HT is doing. Perhaps HT was aware of the problematic material in the book and decided to garner a set of positive reviews to boost sales before the book's official release. I feel as if that money could have been better used to assist Roth in adjusting some of the problematic ideas presented in the book.

column1: I stopped reading at page 66. I was simultaneously bored and unsettled by the book and set it aside. This being said
column2: I do not know how the book ends or develops
column3: and I honestly don't care. Here are the main things I found problematic within those first 66 pages:

column1: 1. The Thuve and the Shotet. The Thuve are presented as a lighter skinned race who are passive. Akos
column2: one of the main characters
column3: views the Shotet as a brutal and fierce race of people (the Shotet killed Akos's grandmother). The first time the readers are introduced to the Shotet
column4: the Shotet arrive to Akos's family farm and brutally murder his father.

column1: 2. The Shotet language is described as harsh and gutteral by Akos compared to his own softer sounding language (who discovers he has the ability to speak other languages without prior conscious knowledge of them). This view of languages is similar to the comparisons of the ""music"" of Romance (white) languages (French
column2: Italian
column3: Spanish) to the ""harsh
column4: guttural"" (black) languages of the African continent.

column1: 3. While the Shotet are described has having varying tones of skin
column2: Cyra's mother is described as having hair curly enough for fingers to be trapped in the curls while Cyra's is not as curly as that. Um. Okay.

column1: 4. Cyra's brother Ryz forcibly trades one of his memories for one of Cyra's. Cyra obviously struggles against it and can't fight it
column2: and you know what? That's rape. Forcing someone to take something mentally (and inevitably physically) is an act of rape. Cyra was raped by her own brother. As a result of that rape
column3: Cyra's power manifests itself as pain. Literally. Pain. By page 66
column4: Cyra cannot touch other people without feeling pain
column5: and other people cannot touch her without feeling pain.

column1: 5. Later
column2: Cyra's mother asks the doctor ""You're saying this gift is my daughter's fault? That she wants to be this way?"" And the doctor (male) says
column3: ""Cyra
column4: the gift comes from you. If you change
column5: the gift will
column6: too."" So a man is telling a woman that her rape and her pain from that rape is her own fault and that she can change it at will. Yep. That's a blatant reinforcement of rape culture.

column1: 6. The religion of the Shotet draws heavily from Islamic ideology. Some of the religious leaders are called clerics
column2: and some of the practices reinforce the negative views the West has on Muslim culture. We need to move past these harmful stereotypes.

column1: 7. While I enjoyed the Divergent trilogy well enough for what it is (even if it's a blatant knockoff of The Hunger Games and Harry Potter
column2: it is also somewhat original in its ending)
column3: Carve the Mark is a lazy reimagining of the Star Wars and X-Men universes. It tries to be unique and diverse
column4: but the glaring insensitivity within the first sixty pages result in its failing.

column1: I was excited for this because there aren't too many science fiction novels lately for the YA audience. However
column2: the problems in the novel fail its readers by relying on outdated
column3: racist tropes that should be a thing of the past in 2017. Science fiction is about creating new worlds
column4: exploring new ideas
column5: and finding some kernel of society to examine. Carve the Mark does none of this. Instead of drawing on redundant
column6: harmful tropes
column7: science fiction should offer the author and the readers the ability to create something new
column8: to flip tropes and reinvent them. It seems as if the editors failed to notice or didn't care
column9: knowing that they'd have a cash-grab with the popular name attached
column10: or it seems as if Roth is privileged enough to be unaware of the damage she has caused with these themes. Maybe it's a combination of both.

column1: Racial stereotyping and cultural misappropriations.
Unflagged trigger warnings.
And a romanticised depiction of chronic pain (something that is very personal to me).
But let's begin with the writing. Wow talk about dull! The first half of this book was so incredibly tedious. The pace
column2: the plotting
column3: the world building (what world building?!?!)... It just dragged. It felt uninspired
column4: insipid
column5: unimaginative
column6: take your pick! Was this book set in space??? It didn't feel like that to me. One of the things that I really didn't like with regards to the writing was the format of switching points of view. It just did not work because it was so poorly executed. It seemed much too haphazard and really hindered the flow of the narrative.

column1: So the basic set up is there are two races of people sharing some planet. They hate each other because *reasons* and hatred & drama ensue.
Okay. Controversy number one: Racist undertones

Many people have been incredibly offended by the depiction of the races in this book saying that it reinforces negative stereotypes within our society. There's a seemingly more civilised race versus a more savage one. Personally I found that there was enough nuance with regard to the diversity of the descriptions of the physical appearances of the two races
column2: but
column3: I think this may have been due to my prior knowledge of this controversy because I was actively reading looking for the differences. If you step back from the book
column4: the overall impression of the two races is not so clear. And there were also worrying descriptors used to ascribe differences between characters
column5: e.g. a reference to curly hair tight enough to capture a finger which is reminiscent of the pencil test used during apartheid times in South Africa to ascertain skin colour. An inadvertent unconscious similarity??? At any rate
column6: I think that conceptually this was a bad idea. Because division of race
column7: even in a fantastical setting
column8: is going to cause problems within our own reality. It is going to offend. And surely that isn't the way forward? I also found a lot of ethnic stereotyping going on in this book. Parts of various cultures being borrowed in a less than savoury manner. Basically at times I felt the book was not carefully researched and therefore did not provide a well thought out and sensitively structured system of beliefs for the people in the story.

column1: Trigger Warning Self Harm At this point I would like to draw your attention to some ritualistic behaviours the Shotet people do regarding marking their bodies. In particular during chapter 13 there is a very detailed description of something that could be incredibly triggering to anyone who has issues regarding self-harm. While I personally am okay with the theory behind this behaviour I strongly feel that there should be a warning on the back cover of this book with regards to this behaviour. When are authors and publishers going to take some responsibility for the possible detrimental effects of the content of their published works???
Back to the story:
The three main characters in this book are:
Cyra
column2: a Shotet girl who experiences chronic pain.

column1: Her power hungry
column2: villainous brother Ryzek.

column1: And then there is Akos
column2: a Thuvhesit boy fated to serve his Shotet enemy.

column1: Let's start with Akos.... I've pretty much nothing to say about him. He was about as interesting as a piece of cardboard. Zero personality. One dimensional. Boring...move on!!!
Ryzek
column2: the big bad. Likes to rape minds and steal memories. He could have been a quite chilling character but his portrayal descended into pantomime theatrics and a sensitive subject such as forcibly taking what you want and thereby violation of another person was very badly handled.

column1: Next controversy: Rape Culture

So Ryzek rapes Cyra's mind thus causing the early onset of her 'currentgift' which leaves her experiencing chronic pain for which she is ultimately told is her fault because she feels she deserves this pain... That bother anyone else??? Reinforce the idea of victim shaming/blaming???
And finally
column2: there is Cyra. She's an interesting character. It's a bold move to attempt to write a character suffering from chronic pain... But was it a move that paid off???

column1: Well with regards to the storyline yes!
With regards to upsetting and offending sufferers of chronic pain then it's a big no.
Chronic pain controversy
So here's a little information about me.

Many of my Goodreads friends will know that from time to time I have mentioned that I suffer from multiple chronic illnesses. (Yes multiple.) And one of those illnesses in particular causes great physical pain. It causes more pain than I could ever possibly explain to you. My chronic pain took hold of my life when I was still a child almost 25 years ago. So I think that living with chronic pain for the best part of a quarter of a century qualifies me to discuss it.

My first problem with Cyra's chronic pain is the terminology used. It is frequently described as a 'currentgift'. In the glossary a currentgift is explained as follows: thought to be a result of the current flowing through a person
column2: currentgifts are abilities
column3: unique to each person
column4: that develop during puberty. They are not always benevolent.

column1: Isn't that last line about this currentgift not always being benevolent great??? As if it somehow excuses you from the offensive terminology of calling the suffering of the main character a 'gift'.
Here's a tip for you. Do not ever call chronic pain a gift. Even if it's in a slightly made-up word that you feel the need to explain in the back of your book.

What really annoyed me in this instance is how Cyra referred to her pain as a gift. I could accept anyone else in the book referring to it as such and put it down to their ignorance and then possibly have Cyra show why it should not be called such a thing... But she FREQUENTLY called it a gift without any hint of irony
column2: derision or sense of injustice!!! Only once did she disagree
column3: but then
column4: instead of referring to the pain in some other manner
column5: she continued on with this gift terminology. My pain is not
column6: and will never be a gift. I will always experience pain. There is no out. And I am incredibly offended by even remotely suggesting that it could possibly be construed as a gift. Where is my gift receipt please because I'm sending this unwanted gift back!!!

column1: Also
column2: my chronic pain is not an ability. An ability???? I don't do magic tricks with it. Unless you want to see how easily I can swallow large painkillers with barely a mouthful of water so I don't vomit!!!!!

column1: Okay. I get where the idea of this character is coming from. And there are aspects to the descriptions surrounding Cyra's pain that I really liked.
The pain was just part of life now. Simple tasks took twice as long because I had to pause for breath
Great stuff! The normality of everyday living changes completely when you live with chronic pain. You don't have an off switch from it
column2: you have different levels of intensity and somehow you get through a day. And everything takes so very long. Even something as simple as getting out of bed in the morning can take hours. If anyone is interested in understanding more about the life of someone with a chronic illness I would love to direct you to ""The Spoon Theory"". It's a very simplistic but beautiful way of expressing what daily life can be like for chronic illness and pain sufferers. I would encourage anyone to read up on it so you can understand what normality is for those people like me who live under the radar with our invisible diseases. You can read all about it HERE.

column1: So here's another problem with the portrayal of chronic pain in the book. It may be stated once or twice that simple tasks take longer etc but I saw no extended periods of fatigue as a result. Cyra was frequently able to fight in a gym type environment... Really??? Like ALL of the time????? Trust me. There are days that no matter how much you try to push through the pain you can't. You just can't. There is insufferable and unending fatigue.
Also
column2: if Cyra was truly in as much pain as she was
column3: she would absolutely have been an insomniac as was stated in the book (case in point I'm writing this review at 4am) but she also would have
column4: at times
column5: passed out from the pain. However
column6: there was one lovely quote I liked that I could very much identify with: That he couldn't feel pain also meant he didn't know about the grey space just beneath consciousness that made it more bearable. I love that grey space. I frequently stay hours in that grey space and don't know where my day has disappeared to all of a sudden. So I needed more moments like this. More explanations to ground Cyra's pain in reality. Pain so often should have consumed her body so much that she would have laid there motionless until unconscious. You often cannot take the pain and that needs to be shown more. It goes to this whole romanticised notion of pain. How suffering is some great beauty.

column1: That brings me to chapter 25 (mild spoiler ahead)
In this chapter Cyra comes to the conclusion that ultimately the gift is the strength the curse has given me... I can bear it. I can bear pain. I can bear anything.

This is insulting and wrong on so many levels. I know that ideologically this is a lovely thought. It goes to the idea that being someone living with pain and fighting through to live another day is admirable.
Look at how stoic she is
column2: so brave
column3: so strong....

column1: So spare me your melodrama!!!
That is an idea for people who don't live with daily pain. It is there
column2: to comfort them. To justify why some people live lives of pain and others don't. It goes to the notion that pain is a burden which is only given to those who are strong enough to carry it.

column1: Not true.

Pain is indiscriminate. Pain corrupts. Pain infiltrates your every fibre of person. It changes you. You don't become strong you become institutionalised to it. You fall back on survival mechanisms. Don't glorify those mechanisms as some sort of admirable strength. I don't want to bear ""anything"" thanks. The pain is quite enough.
It also alludes to a dangerous concept that as pain sufferers we somehow have this skill or ability to take more and more and more. As if we should never feel that the pain is too much???
Trust me
column2: with chronic pain the pain is MUCH too much
column3: and this concept that Cyra thinks that her ability to bear incalculable amounts of pain makes her somehow strong is insulting.

column1: It is okay to not be able to bear unending pain every day.
It is okay to feel like it is too much.
It is okay to need help.
It is okay to not have to suffer in silence.
It is okay to not have to be martyred by pain.

I would also like to have seen a greater emotional impact on Cyra of what it is like to live with pain for so long. I too was a child when pain took hold. I will never forget that first day of experiencing pain. What it was like ripping through my little body.
So where was the hatred? The bitterness?? The why me???
The only self loathing we had on Cyra's part was because of how she inflicted her pain on others and her guilt over that. (Btw
column2: also offensive. I would never wish my pain on another soul so to say that that is something a chronic pain sufferer would do... Yeah... Not impressed!) But I would have much preferred this loathing to be based on the manifestation of her pain and not some outside event.

column1: I haven't even touched on the idea that Cyra's love interest in this story lessens her pain which just adds this book to the myriad of other YA novels out there that tells the reader that love can cure no matter what ails you be it a mental health issue or a physical illness.... At the end of the day
column2: this is a fictional story and Cyra does not suffer from a chronic illness per se (I'm incredibly aware that in future books there is a possibility for a narrative surrounding healing which I hope the author will not explore). But as this is fictional who am I to say that the experiences of Cyra shouldn't be written as they are. Veronica Roth has claimed that she experiences chronic pain and perhaps this is how she feels... It just is not my experience of life with pain.

column1: On the whole this is a very problematic book.
It has issues with poor writing and character development to start with. There are potentially offensive racial undertones
column2: an unflagged trigger warning regarding self-harm and what I believe is an ineffectual representation of chronic pain.

column1: But I don't think that Veronica Roth set out to be racist or ableist or any such thing. I believe that she is just a writer very much out of her depth lacking in proper guidance. I feel there is a sad indictment on the publishing industry that somehow allowed this book to slip through editing and proof reading with the presence of so many questionable aspects.
So my last thoughts on this book are for Ms Roth and for her future writings.
In the words of the great Samuel Beckett:
Ever tried
column2: ever failed
column3: no matter.

column1: Try again
column2: fail again
column3: fail better.""

column1: This book is interesting not because of it's story (which is dull) but because of the circumstances surrounding it's release.
BLACK FACE

Every now and then a book comes along that presents some toxic ideas which are commonly seen in tons of books. But our GoodReads community turns into a hive mind and decides this one book is the absolute worst.
I can't help but feel that this book got unlucky. The Winner's Curse was gushed about despite it's disgusting representation of colonialism and slavery. Sarah Maas had published a dozen books
column2: short stories and novellas before readers started to grumble about the lack of LGBT characters. Mark Lawrence
column3: Prince of Thorns and Patrick Rothfuss got almost no flack for their sexist stereotypes.

column1: So the question becomes- are people outraged by the offensive stereotypes or are they just unable to ignore them because the story was subpar?
Race in fantasy is a difficult thing. Most writers avoid it entirely
column2: it's a chronic truism that if the book is a fantasy then you can assume everyone is white. In Carve the Mark I'm not sure there was any way for Roth to avoid this controversy. She set up a situation in which two cultures clash. Providing any sort of racial markers to either group was going to cause a reaction.

column1: For the criticism of ableism- all I can really add is people who experience disability or chronic pain are likely to have the clearest perspective on this but since there are entire spiritual practices devoted to incorporating pain into knowledge of god it would probably be useful to remember that there is not one right way to write about difficult experiences. The most useful discussion around this stuff is seeing if the writer correctly identified a possible response to a human experience. They aren't representing your experience. If every time a writer tried to write about an experience they don't have personal knowledge of they got lambastedâ€¦ well good luck getting any marginalised experiences into print.
Perhaps the backlash against this novel will be an important marker to writers and publishers alike? God knows I've gritted my teeth thru enough ""white saviour""
column2: ""black aggressor""
column3: ""magical negro"" and ""noble savage"" stereotypes to be eager to see these tropes die out. Maybe Roth's new book is the bloody sacrifice needed to make publishers sit up and take notice? In which case this mediocre book can be said to have done some real good in the literary world.

column1: But I can't help suspecting this novel will be thrown on a pyre righteous of indignation like other outliers before it is ignobly forgotten.
Readers will continue to eat up sexist and racist stories because the characters are swoon worthy
column2: the plot is thrilling or the reader's who object are ""oversensitive sjw's"".

column1: This controversy is food for thought for writers and readers alike. Despite what some people claim stories are important cultural indicators. They shape and define how we experience and respond to the world around us. A story is never ""just a story"" and I'm pleased to see so many fellow readers engaging with subtext and connotation
column2: rather then reviews full of gifs saying ""omfg love interest is soooo hawt"".

column1: BLOOD MONEY

The second thing worth noting was the volume of paid reviews this book has on the front page. There are a ton of studies that show how being financially paid to review a product unconsciously inflates reviewers' scores. This is the first novel I've come across on GR were the front page was saturated with paid reviews. GR has been fiercely defended as a place created for readers by readers (and the bloody remnants of many writing careers can still be found scattered across the site).
In a world of tightly controlled image creation GR members have managed to carve out a space that can be downright vicious to anyone who tries to infiltrate the community for commercial purposes.

As a community we need to think carefully about accepting paid reviews as a common practice. It destroys authenticity. Most regular users are voracious readers. It would be wonderful if we could all earn a living by reading books. But here's the thing: you won't. Even if a tiny fraction of readers manage to earn a living wage reviewing books it will be at the cost of their personal integrity and the community's effectiveness. Goodreads works because it is real. It is genuine word of mouth supercharged across the globe. Marketers might be drooling to get a slice of the PR pie but we as members decide whether that is organic
column2: authentic acclaim or... not.

column1: There is a very real risk if this trend continues that GR will become an advertisement billboard. Our choices now will determine the future of goodreads.

If you see a review that is paid for don't like it. Let the other member know you are unhappy with their decision to accept payment for a review. These are two really easy things members can do to curb these trends. If paid reviews get no ""likes"" and languish on the 20th page publishers won't bother trying to curate the book's image. Likewise
column2: if members see that accepting paid reviews breaks their friends trust
column3: they won't accept them.

column1: How we address commercial encroachment in Good Reads matters. I don't come to GR to read 30 paid ads on the book I'm about to read
column2: do you?

column1: Edit: Some booktubers and reviewers have vigorously defended themselves. I wanted to add evidence to my claim that the inflation in reviews occurs even where the reviewers believe they are being objective :
https://reviewmeta.com/blog/analysis-...
Although this refers to amazon reviews I think it provides sufficient evidence for the same problem on GR.

For further evidence of how fucked up it is having sponsored reviews on goodreads see Riley's review Which describes how her contact was dissolved when she notified the publisher she would be writing a negative review.

column1: As a bit of background
column2: I had actually planned to read this book quite a while back. My experiences with Roth's books have been rocky to say the least. I thought ""Divergent"" was okay (though with issues)
column3: ""Insurgent"" was less okay (with more issues
column4: but it held my attention still) and ""Allegiant"" was just...not good is putting it mildly. But I figured I'd give ""Carve the Mark"" a chance because it had all the bullet points of a series I might like. It's sci-fi
column5: it's set in space
column6: involves political intrigue and manipulation of powers/unique abilities of its cast
column7: has some romantic inclinations
column8: and involves a purportedly epic clash between different groups of people. (I'm deliberately ignoring the comparisons to Star Wars/X-Men because that sets up unrealistic expectations
column9: and I don't buy into that kind of hype.)

column1: I started hearing about issues with this narrative on the day of release
column2: and several of my Goodreads friends and trusted bloggers had mixed reactions to it as well. I'm thinking ""Oh crud
column3: glad I didn't preorder it. I still want to read it
column4: maybe I should just get it from the library if it doesn't have ten billion holds."" On one of my routine trips to my library
column5: I saw the book on the shelf and was wondering like ""Can I actually check this out?"" Turns out I could
column6: and I did
column7: and my initial thoughts were whether I was lucky to get one or if I'd set myself up for disappointment.

column1: The long and short of ""Carve the Mark's"" story centers on the conflict between two space societies: the Thuvue and the Shotet. People in this world have unique abilities called currentgifts
column2: which by definition in the glossary of the story ""develop during puberty. They are not always benevolent."" The story attempts to showcase the perspectives of Akos and Cyra from those nations respectively. Akos and his brother Eijeh
column3: after a series of violent events
column4: are kidnapped by the Shotet and made to use their currentgifts for the benefit of Cyra's family. Eijeh is subjected under the influence of Cyra's tyrannical brother Rhyzek
column5: while Akos uses his abilities to aid Cyra. Cyra is a young woman whose existence is tormented by her currentgift
column6: but yet she enacts her brother's will by serving as a weapon under his direct command. Cyra doesn't want to hurt anyone or serve as her brother's weapon in their kingdom
column7: but her ability impedes her and can't escape the guilt of a secret (read: not so secret) that hangs over her head - both by her brother's influence and her own guilt.

column1: Cyra and Akos have a rocky relationship with competing interests at first
column2: but as they learn about each other's experiences
column3: they grow closer romantically and end up making plans to take Rhyzek down. Of course this journey isn't without a few curveballs (supposedly
column4: I honestly didn't find them that shocking) the narrative throws at the reader in the end
column5: and apparently leaves to continue in this purported duology.

column1: While this summary of the story wouldn't seem so terrible when taken by that barebones approach
column2: there were so many things wrong with ""Carve The Mark"" in execution that it's difficult to know where to begin. The pacing in the novel is atrociously sluggish
column3: starting with very little conflict or explanation and meandering more often than not (I found this to be a similar problem in Roth's ""Alliegiant""). The worldbuilding is weakly drawn from the beginning
column4: and the presentation of the world is awkward and confusing. For a book that blends sci-fi and fantasy in a space centered universe - there's never a chance to become immersed or invested in the environment. Granted
column5: this is a universe where Oracles determine the fates of people with currentgifts and note how their gifts influence the balance of power between the societies. Akos and Cyra come from two powerful families and have powerful gifts that they develop over time
column6: though there isn't much attention to the system by which this works (what little there is comes across as confusing). ""Carve the Mark"" trades between their perspectives
column7: starting with Akos in third person
column8: while Cyra's perspective is written in first person POV.

column1: It was hard to care for any of the cast of characters in this book other than Cyra. Cyra had the more prominent storyline and scenetime
column2: while Akos's perspective suffered from being too emotionally distant despite some purportedly harrowing experiences. Add to the fact that Roth chose to telegraph certain experiences and emotions of the characters - withholding certain revelations key to the storyline for no particular reason at all (and you could guess what those revelations were without getting too far into the storyline - I predicted them fairly quickly.) The narrative would've benefited from them being shown and fleshed out much more than the attention they received. So
column3: the writing and establishment of the plot was much weaker than it would've otherwise been with greater care and time taken to develop the world. Don't even get me started on the one-note side characters and villains. For a reportedly violent sci-fi world with prominent clashes
column4: when certain characters bit the bullet
column5: I found it hard to care because I really didn't feel like I knew the characters in this novel that well. Even Ryzek's motivations felt paperthin despite the attempt to showcase his flaws and eventually the rationale he uses to manipulate his sister into being his weapon of choice to enact his assertion of power.

column1: Cyra and Akos's characters had a few scenes where I could believe in their chemistry and slow burning relationship

column1: Carve the Mark is a thousand miles away from the Divergent Trilogy. The novel is set in a fantastical universe where a literally flowing entity called the Current surrounds nine unique planets. If you've read Under the Never Sky by Veronica Rossi
column2: you can imagine the Current as the aurora-borealis-like Aether. Personally
column3: the Current reminded me of the Lifestream in Final Fantasy VII. :D Anyways
column4: like the Aether in UTNS
column5: the Current in CTM gives humans supernatural abilities. However
column6: in the case of Cyra Noavek
column7: her gift is more like a curse because it racks her body (and others) with constant pain. The story kicks off when she meets Akos Kereseth
column8: a supposed enemy who can nullify the Current and thereby ease her pain. (Trigger warning for Feminists xD)

column1: From the get go

column1: My reading experience became somewhat better when I became familiar with the complex world and the author's quite different writing style (i.e. Cyra's chapters are in first person

column1: Among the many characters in this book

column4: she could be selfless to a fault. Basically
column5: Cyra's uncanny similarity to Tris gave me a feeling of nostalgia
column6: as well as a cynical kind of pleasure. :p

column1: As a final note

column4: I actually did not detect any kind of discrimination against people of color
column5: not all Shotet are dark-skinned ""barbarians

On a planet where violence and vengeance rule

column8: and reset the balance of power in this world?

column1: Cyra is the sister of the brutal tyrant who rules the Shotet people. Cyraâ€™s currentgift gives her pain and powerâ€”something her brother exploits

column1: Akos is from the peace-loving nation of Thuvhe

column1: What I Liked:
Carve the Mark is absolutely worth the hype and the excitement
column2: and it's definitely worth your time to read this book if you've been looking forward to reading it. Chances are
column3: it won't disappoint you. In many ways
column4: I liked this book a lot. But there were several specific things that might seem small or insignificant in the grand schemes of things
column5: that ended up really bothering me. Hence
column6: the three-star rating.

column1: This story is told by two characters - Akos
column2: a Thuvhe
column3: and Cyra
column4: a Shotet. The Thuvhe are a peace-loving people living on Urek. The Shotet are more aggressive nomadic people that conquer various nations and planets. When he is fourteen
column5: Akos is captured
column6: along with his brother
column7: by the Shotet
column8: who kill his father in front of him. They are taken to the Shotet stronghold of Urek
column9: ruled by Ryzek Noavek
column10: a ruthless tyrant and older brother of Cyra. They are stolen for their currentgifts - Akos's brother Eijeh is the next oracle of the Thuvhe. Akos grows into his currentgift - he can interrupt the current (he can cancel it out
column11: turn it off
column12: that sort of thing). Several years later
column13: Akos is shaped into a warrior
column14: but he has lost known of his humanity. He is not a killer
column15: though he has killed to protect himself. He is brought to help Cyra Noavek
column16: whose currentgift is inflicting pain on others with her touch. No one can touch her without feeling pain
column17: but Akos can
column18: because he interrupts the current (and all currentgifts are ""fueled"" by the current). Akos cooperates because he wants to rescue his brother and flee. But the more he and Cyra interact
column19: the more they learn about each other
column20: and the more they realize that they share common interests

column1: The beginning of the book was incredibly confusing (I'll talk about that in the next section)
column2: but once I (sort of) got a grasp of the world and everything going on
column3: I started to get into the story and really sink into it. This is science fiction
column4: though certain elements (like the currentgifts) can definitely be categorized as fantasy. This story takes place across planets of a galaxy
column5: so it's a space-y type of science fiction.

column1: I must say
column2: Roth did an excellent job with the characterization and character growth
column3: specifically in terms of Cyra and Akos. I'll start with Akos. He is easily my favorite character of the book. He is Thuvhe
column4: and so he is brought up to be more peaceful and somewhat passive towards violence. Even several years being trained as a Shotet soldier doesn't break him down. He is compassionate
column5: and he is strong. I liked him a lot
column6: especially for his unbreakable will. I was amazing and in awe of how much pain and grief and despair he bore
column7: for years. Akos grows into a character that still hates killing
column8: and is sick over having to kill anyone
column9: but can do it. He becomes so strong and capable in other ways
column10: and he's also extremely intelligent and clever. He isn't an alpha type of YA hero - he's quietly intelligent and very
column11: very human.

column1: Cyra is almost the opposite of him
column2: yet it slowly becomes apparent that she has similarities to him. She appears to be a brutal
column3: cold
column4: emotionless killer summoned and used by her brother
column5: Ryzek. But Cyra does not enjoy wielding her painful power over others
column6: and she definitely does not enjoy bending to Ryzek's will. In many ways
column7: it is Akos who shows her mercy
column8: what mercy is
column9: and that she is still capable of being merciful
column10: and better
column11: and more. Cyra learns to turn her pain into something else. She loses none of her deadliness and her danger
column12: but as the story goes on
column13: she becomes stronger and more able to stand up to Ryzek.

column1: Once I got past the first one hundred pages or so
column2: I had little difficulty getting through the story. I was pretty engrossed and despite the book being rather long
column3: I read it quickly. There is so much happening in this story
column4: and I wanted to see how it would all end. There were so many moments when things could go disastrously wrong
column5: and I held my breath as I turned the pages. No one can say that certain parts of this book weren't engrossing. A lot of the story ends up being about how to unseat Ryzek
column6: and how to stay alive and protect each other.

column1: There is romance! I liked seeing Akos and Cyra fall for each other. It's actually Cyra who shows her feelings first
column2: which you wouldn't expect. Cyra is supposedly the more ruthless one
column3: and Akos is the more emotional and merciful one. But it's Cyra that starts to fall for Akos first
column4: and shows her hand first. I liked their dynamic a lot - they learn to trust each other before anything else. No love triangle! Thank goodness for that. I thought this romance was well-developed
column5: and swoony towards the end.

column1: There is also another romance which I thought was sweet. I can't say much about it because it'll spoil things
column2: but it's between two characters that are good together.

column1: The ending
column2: as insane and chaotic as it is
column3: is not a cruel ending. There is no horrible cliffhanger
column4: which is surprising
column5: since this is book one of a duology. You'd expect something really terrible to have happened at the end
column6: hurting the main character(s). Don't get me wrong
column7: terrible (permanent) things definitely happened
column8: but the ending isn't a cliffhanger
column9: and I definitely appreciate that.

column1: Now I'm going to talk about the things I didn't really enjoy.
What I Did Not Like:
First: the initial one hundred pages or so? Very confusing
column2: and very boring too. I had a hard time getting through the beginning of the story. There is so much information dumped into the first couple of chapters
column3: and so many names. It also took me a while to realize that the beginning is when Akos is fourteen - and NOT the ""present"" time of the story. Same with Cyra's beginning - she is six when her chapter begins. The beginning has too much going on
column4: and it isn't well-explained at first. I had to reread several of the chapters a few times to really get some sort of grasp as to what was happening.

column1: I'm not sure I really understand the world/world-building? Currentgifts and their origin and how/why they exist still kind of elude me. What is the ""current""? Where did it come from? How is it magically given people these currentgifts? The currentgifts are things like inflicting pain upon touch
column2: or not feeling pain at all
column3: or seeing the future
column4: or seeing every memory of a person.

column1: Second: there are so many awful
column2: brutal scenes in this book. I'm talking about torture and cruel treatment of people. I understand that this type of brutality is very real and exists in real life and has a place in this fictional world
column3: but the brutality of a lot of it... didn't sit well with me. Usually a certain level of violence doesn't bother me too much? The violence in this book
column4: while not exactly graphic
column5: is horrifying. Which is probably the intent
column6: but my stomach hurt
column7: reading it.

column1: Third: Not the biggest thing I didn't like
column2: but I wasn't a huge fan of having Akos's POV in third-person
column3: and then Cyra's in first-person. I loved reading from both of their POVs! But it would have been nice to have a little uniformity (either both in first
column4: or both in third). Also it already scares me
column5: that Roth chooses to tell this story from both Akos and Cyra's POVs. We saw what happened in Allegiant...

column1: Fourth: problematic racial content. Oh yeah
column2: I definitely see where people are coming from
column3: when they say that this book has some racist content. The Shotet are portrayed as ""brown skinned""
column4: aggressive
column5: nomadic people. They stole Thuvhe children years ago
column6: and the Thuvhe retaliated and stole Shotet children
column7: but the way the story is told
column8: the Shotet are the ""villains"". I mean
column9: given that the first chapter is about Akos's father getting brutally murdered in front of him
column10: I get why that would be implication. But there are definitely underlying tones of something problematic here: the Thuvhe
column11: light-skinned peaceful people
column12: and the Shotet
column13: darker-skinned aggressive people
column14: are both cliches. And what's more
column15: it seems like most of the Shotet have very violent currentgifts
column16: whereas the Thuvhe have more passive
column17: non-violent gifts (like Akos's
column19: or his brother's).

column1: Do you see the problem here? Why is it that the ""aggressive"" people are always the brown/darker-skinned ones
column2: and the more ""peaceful"" non-violent people are lighter-skinned? I have no qualms with the characters themselves (I adore Akos
column3: and Cyra is such a fighter)
column4: but the social construct here is reflective of cliches and stereotypes.

column1: Read THIS peace if you want more information. I definitely do not know it all
column2: but I recognize and understand the issue at hand here
column3: in terms of race and culture.

column1: Would I Recommend It:
Yes
column2: I had issues with this book
column3: and I firmly believe that last issue needs to be addressed. And yes
column4: I also enjoyed the book
column5: for the most part
column6: regardless. It's a good story
column7: and I was definitely swept up in the story as I was reading. I'll be reading the sequel next year. I don't know if I really should recommend this book
column8: given the evident issues. But I did like the story too. If you've been excited to read this book
column9: believe me
column10: it probably won't disappoint. But... recognize issues when you see them. Talk about them. Discuss and learn.

column1: Rating:
3 stars. Like I said
column2: this is a good story
column3: and of all of Roth's books
column4: it's probably her best. I think I liked it more than I liked her other books (definitely more than I liked Insurgent and Allegiant - though I never fully read Allegiant). I want to see where the story goes. But there were some things that held me back a little

My life has been broken up into two segments: before Evelyn and after.

Where do I even start with this? If all of my enthusiasm and relentless energy could be compressed into a grenade I would pull the pin out for The Seven Husbands of Evelyn Hugo and burst into a show of sparkles and champagne bubbles. I don't even know how to concisely put into words how much this book did the damn thing for me.
So do yourself a favor and learn how to grab life by the balls
column2: dear. Don't be so tied up in trying to do the right thing when the smart thing is so painfully clear.

column2: luscious

column1: Evelyn Hugo. She spent her entire life working tirelessly and mercilessly to fight her way to the top of the food chain during the Golden Age of Hollywood. column2: little-known

column1: This is the first book Iâ€™ve read in a while where I sat and read without touching my phone for 2+ hours
column2: praying that time would pass slower so I could fit in more pages before I had to go to sleep. Part of why I was so addicted is because the writing of this book just demands attention. Itâ€™s flowing almost to the point of conversational
column3: more like a memoir than a novel. And although I flew through the prose
column4: part of me questions whether the flashback sections resemble the tone and voice of an older Hollywood star. A lot of the lingo and style of relating a story seemed modern
column5: and maybe Iâ€™m just overthinking
column6: but it took away a bit from the authenticity of the story for me. Maybe it would have worked better being told in third person as if it were Monique's writing
column7: but something about the voice of Evelyn's memories didn't sit right with me.

column1: I like how this book uses the perspective of hindsight. Evelyn using her wisdom to call out when she was being mistreated and all the unjust and toxic things that occurred to her constructed a powerful narrative. I applaud this book talking about feminism
column2: abusive relationships
column3: abortions
column4: and bisexual erasure
column5: among plenty other things. I can see why it's highly praised in that respect. The discussion of moral greyness and the corruption and scheming of Hollywood and fame and unabashed conceit and fame was also fascinating. I love the light in which it was painted. It was very take it or leave it
column6: which was so different because usually
column7: books do the most to try and convince you of a character being starkly good or bad. This book let you assume whatever you wanted to about the characters
column8: which I respected.

column1: Lastly
column2: the most satisfying thing about this book is watching the growth of Monique alongside Evelyn telling her story. Being honest
column3: I didn't think I was going to like Evelyn at first
column4: but I realized the same quality that makes her a rude and off-putting character also makes her powerful and memorable. I grew to love her snark and confrontational dialogue
column5: even though I would likely be terrified of her in person.

column1: It's hard to wrap up this review because I want to say that I loved it as much as everyone else
column2: but I can't quite put my finger on why it wasn't a full five stars. Still
column3: I highly recommend it. (less)",590,NEXTBOOK

column1: When you're given an opportunity to change your life
